entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON NEC
entry.content:
Last Sunday afternoon, 2020 21st Dec, I finished my NEC exam.

I have prepared for the exam since I decided to take part in it. When the words ‘EXAM IS OVER’ appeared on my screen, I was a little bit disappointed because there were many questions which I found I could not do anything with.

About four months ago, when I talked to my Economics teacher Ms.Cindy, I heard about NEC for the first time. She told me that NEC is National Economics Challenge and advantages and disadvantages of it. I decided to take part in it as I discovered that I am really interested in Economics.

Then, I discussed with my friends. We founded a group called ‘Together Group’ because we hoped that everyone in our group can always be together and support each other during preparation.

At the beginning, we four were all very positive, energetic and active. Tiffany found some lessons online, while Leo borrowed some books like Baron. Yuki and I collected and sorted all the materials we had. We even attended the CCA for NEC every Tuesday afternoon. This was the most impressive part in this activity, as Together Group gave me the feeling of a family.

Gradually, two of us started to lose confidence as other students are stronger than us in Economics. Yuki and I kept on taking classes and reading Mankind’s Principle of Economy. During this stage, I noticed that it became easier for me to understand some knowledge we learn in normal classes by Ms.Cindy.

Before the exam, I knew that it was almost impossible for my Together Group to get into next turn as it counted the top three marks in a group. However, I didn’t choose to give up because for a very long time I have believe that after the winter, there will always be the spring and when I do a thing, especially as a group member, I need to try my best to finish it because it is my responsibility and if I do, I can grow stronger. Several night before the exam, I stayed up late until mid-night and wrote a pile of notes. When collecting them after exam, strong sense of pride and achievement.

I haven’t get the result of the exam. However, I believed that everything will be well although we may not get into next turn to take part in the NEC China Finals, because I have done my best and insisted the belief in my heart for years.

From NEC Preliminary, I got to know that when I decide to do something, it is better for me to finish it without distractions, because when I act as this, I will become stronger and stronger.

entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON Physics Bowl
entry.content:
On 27th March, around two o’clock in the afternoon, I finished 2021 Physics Bowl.

That was a nice afternoon which is windy and cloudy. The paper was not very hard as the Electromagnetism didn’t appear too many times which is my drawback among all pieces of knowledge. The boy sitting on my left, finished his paper very quickly and seemed to be very confident about his answers.

I was a little bit upset that day. Two things were always on my mind.

To be honest, during the long preparation for Physics Bowl, I gave up half way instead of insisting on training past papers and getting through the book after class. I still remembered the first lesson of Physics Bowl taken by me at the beginning of the first semester of Senior1. During that time, Physics was my favourite subject and I even set it as my target major in the university. However, I started to learn more about both Physics and Economics. Economics is a new subject to me which I refused to study before entry of senior high school but was deeply attracted after getting to understand some basic knowledge. By contrast, it was unbelievable that it began hard for me to understand the complicated concepts in Physics which ran out all my patience and interest. With further study in Economics competition, more time was devoted to Economics instead of Physics. It was a process that happened during a long period, but I still remembered clearly some small moments like I was almost driven crazy by Physics for the first time. From then on, I knew that the story between Physics and I may be near the ending. Another thing happened is that I did some program study those days and read more books about both Nature Science and Social Science especially Economics. A strange feeling of thirsty of concentrating more on Economics came to my heart due to the books I read. I talked to my parents, counsellor and Economics teacher several times. They all hoped that I could insist on what I really love.

AMC teaches me the real meaning of opportunity costs. Physics Bowl may teach me something about giving up.

Many teachers say I am a girl who has a strong demand for perfection, because it is common for me to take part in all the meaningful activities and play an active role in finishing tasks, in order to get satisfying result, even if I dislike the activities or lack time. During the preparation, everyday I was so busy to deal with every details in my life as many events had similar date, that it was difficult for me to calm down and go through the day again, so I decided to give up something to chill myself and reflect more.

I decided to give up Physics Bowl as a result of a lack of incentive of further study due to decreasing interest in Physics. Maybe we can regard this decision as a kind of releasing myself.

I would always be thankful for Physics Bowl as it helped me to discover that maybe it is so suitable for me to spend the rest of time learning Physics but Economics. Also, it provided me with a chance to think about giving up which is a thing I had never though about before. I don’t think that giving up equals to escaping. It is that choose to not choose something in our life because we may hope to choose other things. This is kind of admiration of being ourselves.

entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON AMC and AIME
entry.content:
On 5th and 11th February, I finished my two AMC exams.

AMC is American Mathematics Competition. It is one of the most popular and welcomed maths competition all over the world. During primary school, I used to take part in AMC8 and receive a relative high score(Top 2.5%). As a result, after attending senior high school, AMC became one of my after-class activities as well, because I wanted to challenge myself through it.

During my process of preparation, I felt a little bit lonely from time to time, as there were only a few students in my class choosing to try AMC12 which is beyond the current syllabus.

I tried to talk with August who prepared for AMC12 too, about the exam preparing. We discussed questions from time to time after that. Now, we are good friends. This is the most impressive part of the activity.

I started to understand that although we may compete with each other during the competition, it is still important and possible for us to cooperate, as a result of friendship. Competition is more than competing. August and I received satisfied scores. I got 103.5points in AMC10A and 117points in AMC12B.

Additionally, through AMC, one thing has become clearer than before. The process of improving, challenging and studying may be lonely because everyone makes different decision during this period. For example, my best friend Estella chose to forgo AMC as she wanted to take part in FBLA more. Another example is that during the last preparing day, August and I still had a lot of things which we had not learnt and understood. We chose to study different areas.

From my point of view, the aloneness is one of the lessons we need to learn during our studying time.

Fortunately, I got the chance to take part in AIME(America Invitational Mathematics Examination). However, something unexpected happened. The date of AIME was conflicted with my school IGCSE mock examination. I said to myself several time, “Mock is more important as it is the first time for me to experience international examinations hold by CAIE and mock exam will be the source of GPA of this semester.” Every time the sense of not convinced also came to my heart as it really took me hours and hours learning maths knowledge and going through past papers.

Finally, I decided to give up preparing for AIME to save time for mock exams. After handing in my AIME paper, I got to know that this time I must have been failed to achieve anything. It was near 8 p.m. when AIME was done. Block 1912 opposite my school was still full of music sounds and colourful lights. Suddenly, one concept which I learnt in Economics came to my mind——opportunity cost and made me feel relived.

Everyone has limited time and energy, but I always long for finishing everything which is unattainable and impossible. As a result, it is necessary for me to make a decision on what to do. Opportunity cost is the next best choice foregone when making a decision. I still remember the words which were said by my Economics teacher Ms. Cindy when I told her that I would switch my future major from Physics to Economics. She said that, “Every decision or choice has an opportunity cost. I simply hope that you can consider the thing carefully before making a decision.”

Perhaps to Estella, she though FBLA was more important than AMC so she made such a decision that high prize was rewarded to her by FBLA but not so good performance was shown by her in AMC. To me, I still hope to achieve higher marks in IGCSE instead of AIME.

To sum up, I will always remember AMC and AIME of this year. They provides me with a chance to experience the concept of opportunity costs by myself instead of leaving it only as a piece of knowledge in my Economics books.

Meantime, after seeing the lights and hearing the sounds from Block 1912, I am not regretted about my decision anymore, although a total of only 4 marks was achieved by me in AIME, because I still realised that life sucks, so it may be better for me to be cute and enjoy and try to get understand the tastes of life more, instead of giving myself too much press to spend time seeing the around world.

entry.title: Some records on Being Teaching Assistant
entry.content:
During the revision for IGCSE, my economic teacher Ms. Cindy used the way of letting students act as teaching assistants to review the knowledge.

I was asked to go over the three sections on Macroeconomics. This was quite surprising because the three sections on Microeconomics which has even fewer knowledge points than Macroeconomics were allocated to three students in class. At that time, sense of responsibility came to my heart suddenly.

After that, I started to think about what to review and how to review. From my point of view, the details of Macro are linked together with strong logic, so I chose to use mind map. It really took me a lot time to finish the whole mind map although at the same time I was busy preparing for not only IGCSE but also competitions including IEO and Euclid, and the final presentation of several subjects.

Everything was finished perfectly before the revision day. Ms. Cindy spent several noon discussing the details in mind map with me, so I was exactly confident. Every details was excellent and Ms. Cindy praised me a lot .

Afterwards, I thought about why Ms. Cindy would like to provide me with this chance to challenge myself, although she always says that I am too shy or too nervous to give public speeches behind the whole class.

I could not help asking her about the reason. She smiled and looked at me quietly. Several seconds later, she told me that she hoped that I could practice my speech ability through this presentation. Meanwhile, the process of giving presentation would contribute to my Economics study, as she always looked forward for me to receiving a high mark in IGCSE Economics.

This is not privilege. It is the nice relationship between Ms. Cindy and I that inspires her to do that. The hundreds of afternoons spent together discussing all kinds of problems will be in my memory, which help me make connection with her. My junior high school head teacher once told me that if you want to get to understand someone else or make friends, the best way is to make connection with him or her through communicating and paying attention.

Being teaching assistant teaches me that in order not to let down other’s expectation, it may be better for us to try our best and give a perfect result as possible as we can. Meanwhile, communicating and paying attention are the best way to build an admired relationship as both sides make efforts.

entry.title: Some records on IEO(International Economics Olympiad)
entry.content:
I took part in International Economics Olympiad China Open Round on 11th April.

It was two weeks after my mock exams and three days after Euclid Mathematics Contest. Meanwhile, as the semester was near the end, most subjects final projects which had great influence on my GPA had the deadline at that week, including Economics, Business, Music and Visual Art.

Working to deadline is always my preference. However, after the mock exam, when going through the schedule, a reality came to me which was that the work was so much that it was almost impossible for me to deal with in just one week. I needed to make a plan ahead instead of missing deadline or finishing things curtly.

The plan was like that on Monday I needed to finish the outliner of Business project which would take me around 1 hour and the first part of Economics mind map which would take me about 2 hours. I thought I could finish everything perfectly and with high quality with the help of the plan.

However, the truth is that as it was difficult for me to estimate the time needed accurately, the plan was not completed at the first day, because Business outliner took me too much time. Every time when the time was not enough I chose to give up IEO.

I still understood that IEO was very important, because it is not a personal competition, but a team competition. I need to spend time preparing it as it is essential for me to be responsible to my teammate no matter whether they are responsible to me. The only thing I could do was to ask Economics teacher Ms. Grace for help.

I talked to Ms. Grace and asked her whether she could provide us with several office hours to go through the syllabus. She agreed. As Ms. Grace is an Economics teacher, she does not know about Business and Finance(30% of points were about Business and Finance). I hoped to read A-Level Business book to make sure I can solve the problems during the exam, but there was too much knowledge and too short time to finish. I went to my Business teacher Ms. Cindy. She provided me with a summarised book and several advices. The night before the exam, I spent about 8 hours finishing reading and understanding the book until 3 a.m.. I do not praise what I have done because enough sleeping is exactly important for us. I am still happy with is, as the result of discovering how interesting Business and Finance are and having the courage to challenging myself.

After finishing the exam, I knew that although I may not do IEO well and get low marks, I had tried my best and would not be guilty for not doing well. The result did not mean too much because the experiences and the feelings of challenging were more important.

To sum up, IEO taught me two lessons. The first one is that sometimes we maybe can not follow the plan, so it is important for us to both leave some spare time when making plan and record why we can not finish it to make sure the same thing will not happen for a second time. In addition, follow what you believe and you will find yourself improved through this process. Meanwhile, the whole universe will come to help you when you really want to achieve a thing, so you will gain more, such as the friendship between Ms. Cindy and I.

entry.title: Some records on HSYLC — Why HSYLC
entry.content:
HSYLC is HCAUSCR (Harvard College Association for US-China Relations) Summit for Young Leaders in China. I first heard about it from my friend Estella.

At first, I was thinking about whether to apply to this activity. I was worrying about the writing sample. I did not have high-quality writing sample, because most of my works are just for recording my feelings or my thoughts, instead of analysing the whole passage like formal book review. I spent some time going through all my works and finally found several self-satisfied ones. Finally, I decided to apply for it. To be honest, I did not think much at that time. Maybe because of the experience of rejecting the offer from UWC, I think more choices can provide me with a chance to meet a better world based on my personal condition.

I was so lucky that I was able to receive an interview invitation and a final offer.

By the end of July, COVID-19 broke out again in Nanjing, my city, and everything had been changed. I received the call from the organisers. They told me that I would not be able to take part HSYLC any more because of the breakout. However, several days later, they decided to have everything online. I started to think about——why HSYLC, because at the same time, I had a variety of tasks could do.

Why HSYLC?

Firstly, it is an activity which brings students all around the country together. This provides with a chance to meet more people and have a better understanding of celebration of difference which is one of my values. Because I think I am a little bit introverted and nervous, I want to develop a more confidence characteristic. If I want to achieve this, in the following semester, I can talk to my schoolfellow in IB Diploma Curriculum more. Because some of them have great confidence and can let me understand how they perform in some social events.

Also, I want to learn some special subjects there. For example, it provides classes about Finance and Economics. There are all kinds of lessons like Business Management, Financial Plan or Insurance and Reinsurance. However, because HSYLC is more like a social event, the knowledge I can learn is really limited. I can learn some courses on the online course websites like Coursera to achieve this aim easily.

Last but not least, I still want to practice the teamwork. By the end of last semester, I was a member of SALT FISH Group when taking part in WWW Project (Week Without Wall Project). Something unpleasant happened in our group and I felt extremely tired. I hope that I could have a chance to experience group work again in order to understand what is the most proper way for me to do it in the future. Maybe I can corporate with my friend Yuki to develop a website about Industrial Research. This can help me achieve teamwork and accumulate Economics experiences at the same time.

To sum up, it may be better for me to give up HSYLC. However, I still decided to take part in it, because I think it would be an unforgettable experience in my senior high school life.

entry.title: Some records on HSYLC — Spark in Science Lessons
entry.content:
I chose to learn several science related subjects during HSYLC.

The first one is called How technology contributes to future education. It briefly introduced the use of technology in our daily education. For example, some primary or secondary schools in Shanghai use AI (Artificial Intelligence) to carry on some Physics experiment. This can effectively reduce the danger of accidents happened during the real experiment.

The second one is called Introduction to Web Development and Programming. We learned the basic logic and simple sentence and grammar in Language HTML, CSS and JavaScript. We use them together to design a website as the final homework.

The programming languages, based on my understanding, are more like tools which can be used for achieving some tasks which may include writing a website or collecting and collaborating some data to work out the trend. We can definitely design a website for the students from primary school and secondary school. This website can provide them with almost all the resources during the school day. This makes it much easier for them to do some self-study at home because of the accessibility of studying materials. Also, the website should have the ability to design a simple study plan for the students. As we think low-grade students may not have understood how to plan their time well or make a SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant and Time-scale specific) plan. However, it may still have several problems, like as we have the website for them to design plans for them, this may create disincentive for students to plan their time by themselves. They may even refuse to make a plan, because of a lack of planning skills and understanding about their personal condition.

I think the classes related to Education more provides me with an understanding about how to design a class or how to create incentive for students. The programming languages, including HTML, CSS and JavaScript, also Python I learnt before by myself, are skills which help me achieve my ideas in areas like eduction.

entry.title: Some records on HSYLC —— Sparks in Economics and Business Lessons
entry.content:
Because I am a student who is really interested in Economics and Social Science, I chose Economics as my main major in HSYLC. As a result, several lessons are related to Economics and Business Studies.

For example, my concentration seminar is Introduction to Insurance & Reinsurance Industry, Actuarial Science and Insurance Consulting. Also, I need to complete a short essay about What’s the Influence of Registration System Reform on China’s Stock Market?

When learning about Insurance and Reinsurance Industry, we spent most of our time understanding different concepts, such as, premium, first layer and so on. I still remember that during preparation of IGCSE, I made a clear definition list for all the concepts. The list helped me to go through all the definitions and have a clear understanding about what the concept exactly means. Maybe this is one way of learning Social Science subjects. Understanding different concepts in Insurance makes further calculation more easily.

Calculation makes me worried. It is not about I did not know how to calculate. It is more about calculation is very simple or following some steps. From my point of view, this can be replaced by computer or programs in the future. Also, when looking at the Stock Market, I found it most of the data can be collected and analysed by the computer.

I started to think the link between computer science and social science. It seems that nowadays most research and application in social science are more quantitive instead of qualitative. We prefer to use a huge set of data to find a general trend instead of just working out something based on the “common sense”.

entry.title: Some records on IPQ -- Thinking on peer pressure
entry.content:
During the summer holiday, I attended some class to complete my Independent Project Qualification (IPQ). There are several students from other cities like Shanghai, Beijing or Shenzhen. We took lessons together.

One day, I had dinner with some students from Ulink College which is a famous A-Level school in Shanghai. They were talking about their study of A-Level. I was so surprised that, we are students of the same grades. However, they have already finished what I will study in the future two years. I was deeply influenced and felt anxious, stressed and worries. After that, I spent several hours thinking about what I can do in the future to make myself being able to compete with them.

My teacher Ms. Diao told me this was the result of peer pressure.

What is peer pressure? Wikipedia defines it as the direct influence on people by peers, or the effect on an individual who is encouraged and wants to follow their peers by changing their attitudes, values or behaviours to conform to those of the influencing group or individual.

To be honest, I have been suffered from peer pressure even since I was in my junior high school. At that time, I was always the second place in my class. It seemed that it was impossible for me to become the first. As a result, during the final year, the question which was whether I could become the first in class appeared in my mind everyday. After becoming a student in senior high school, I always worried about getting lower scores than my classmates or attending fewer activities than my classmates, because these will make me weaker than them when applying for universities.

Why I have peer pressure? This is the question coming to my mind, because I know when solving some problems, it is important for us to know the cause of the problems.

We are living in the society and are members of many organisations. For example, I am a member of my class. At the same time, I am a member of my family, my school, my project teams. Partners act important roles in my life. My friends in class are my partners. My parents are my partners as well. But I know that my friends and my parents are of huge difference. They are in different ages. They have different relationship with me. They provide me with and I give them different things.

Peers are our partners who are in similar ages with us.

I never worry about why I can not do the same things as my parents at present, but I used to be trapped in the problem why I could not achieve same grades in school as my parents did when they were in school. This is another kind of peer pressure.

As I mentioned above, we are members of many organisations. This provides us with a platform to see people who have connection with us. It is almost human-beings’ instinct to compare, because everyone wants to prove that themselves are the best. There is an old saying in China—“The beauty is loved by all”. We hope that we are the beauty because we are a member of “all” as well.

Peer pressure is everywhere in our daily life. We could not help us comparing with others in all aspects.

When looking at the consequences of peer pressure, things become more interesting. Some people say that peer pressure provides them with energy to continue working, while others think that it stops them from becoming better and better because of the heavy heart of gain and loss.

Actually, everyone pays attention to different things. Nichole, my best friend, worries about her emotions more, because she has been suffered from bipolar affective disorder for a long time. Yuki, my dest mate, may worry about the relationship between her boyfriend and her more. By comparison, I pay most of my attention to my study, including the grades, the activities, the achievements, the competitions and so on. This is the reason why after listening talks to the students from Ulink I became anxious and stressed.

I know that we are in different platform because we are students from different schools. I know that they are in Shanghai which is a more developed city than Nanjing. I know that they have been in the international system of education longer than me. However, I do hope that I can do as well as them instead of falling behind them.

In order to solve this problem, I talked to my junior high school Physics teacher Ms. Jiao, my senior high school Economics and Business teacher Ms. Cindy, and my counsellor Ms. Diao. They all hope me to pay less attention to others and just be myself, instead of being influenced by others. From my point of view, this is almost impossible for me. I made up my mind to develop several hobbies and separate my attention. Also, I will try my best to become better and better.

Ms. Diao’s parting advice to me during my birthday is very impressive, “Take it easy. Grow up slowly.”

entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON AMC12A
entry.content:
It was in the afternoon of 11th November. I just completed my Mid-term exams and received satisfying scores in several subjects, while some of them were not so good. It seemed that I could not have much time preparing for AMC.

I thought in Senior 1, I got 117 in AMC12B. As a result, it may not be very difficult for me to get a similar score in this year’s AMC12. However, when starting to go through the past papers, I found that most questions became very strange for me to solve.

This year, 2021, I spent most of my time studying Economics and Economics related subjects, instead of paying much attention as I did in 2022. This made my ability in Mathematics decreased a lot. Also, I started to use calculators, instead of working out the solution by hand. This cause my poor calculation ability as well. Still, compared with last year, I spent only several days preparing for it. Last year, I spent almost the whole winter holiday studying new pieces of knowledge and practising past papers. This is because my aim of taking part in had changed. Last year, I hope that I could get a high score and a satisfying prize. However, this year, I just wanted to test my mathematics ability in order to provide guideline for my future preparation for admission test like STEP or MAT or TMUA.

I would not be dissatisfied if I would not get a score above 100 or whatever get a prize, because I knew that I did not pay much attention to this competition. I still remember that, my junior high Mathematics teacher once told us that, “You cannot get a score which is beyond your recognition, unless depending on the fortune”. This statement is always what I tell myself when preparing for an exam and during the releasing of the grade. This is another change of me made by competitions like AMC, which is that I am able to accept the results more peacefully.

To sum up, this year AMC12A will not get a high score. I am sure about this. But, I am happy with the changes I made and several things I realised during this process.

However, there is a conflict between our problem and the chance of providing regular lessons. We do not have the ability to provide lessons for the students, but we can not find professional teachers to do this.

Starting and leading a club is more about having it. We need to think about how to held activities and when to held activities and for whom to held activities.

entry.title: Some more records on IEO(International Economics Olympiad)
entry.content:
In the evening of 28th April, I received the result of IEO.

Surprisingly, our team pass Open Round and get the chance to take part in China Final Round. Meanwhile, I personally got First Prize.

As soon as I got the result, I sent messages to Ms. Cindy who helped me a lot prepare Business and Finance part in IEO. She said, ‘God! Congratulations!’ Then, I told her that I really thanked her as she provided me with both help with learning Business knowledge and the incentive to continue doing instead of giving up. She said, ‘Sylvia, it is mainly you. Please come back with a grand prize in the final round!’

While being inspired by Ms. Cindy’s words, one of my teammate told me that he may not be able to take part in Final Round because of the time conflict with another competition. I was kind of upset and hoped that miracle would happen, but it didn’t happen.

This makes me rethink about responsibility. To prepare for the examination, I stayed up late and got up early to make sure that I would not hinder my teammates. However, when the result came out, the truth is that I get the highest points, although all my teammates got higher marks than me in a previous competition. However, I still reflected myself.

What is responsibility after all? It is the willingness and ability to respect the others and makes sure that you finish your duty fully. Maybe deciding to form a team with my current team is an action which is not responsible to myself as I didn’t talk to them about my aim before making the decision. Still, I didn’t ask my teachers for suggestion although we are from different classes and know little about each other.

To sum up, IEOC provides me with a chance to think about the responsibility again. I started to understand that the most important thing is to be responsible to myself and the to others. After this, all the teamwork may be completed successfully and happily.

entry.title: Section4 Mainly on Population
entry.content:
Factors affected

Natural increase

  • Birth rate

    • Definition: Birth rate is the number of births in a year per 1000 population in a year

    • Result

      • The higher a country’s birth rate, the greater its population growth will tend to be.

    • Causes of high birth rate

      • Women are not well-educated and they don’t work
      • It is cheap to bring up children
      • Lack or disapproval of family planning
      • Government cash incentives to have children but a lack of government help to care for the sick and elderly

    • Similar measure

      • Fertility rate
      • Infant mortality rate

  • Death rate

    • Definition: It is the number of the deaths in a year per 1000 population a year

      • Better-quality education, healthcare, nutrition and sanitation, people in MEDCs tend to live longer.
      • Famine, poverty, poor housing, high infant mortality rates and diseases tend to reduce life expectancy in LEDCs.

    • Result

      • The lower the death rate, the more population the country has

    • Causes of low death rate

      • Healthy diets
      • Good housing facilities
      • Access to high quality medical care
      • Healthy lifestyles
      • Enjoy good working conditions
      • Non-involvement in military action

Net migration

  • Components

    • Definition: It is the difference between immigration and emigration
    • Definition: Immigration occurs when people enter a country to live and work
    • Definition: Emigration occurs when people leave a country to live and work abroad.

  • Results

    • Net immigration

      • There is an excess in immigration

    • Net emigration

      • There is an excess in emigration

      • Consequences

        • Disadvantages

          • Size of working population is likely to be reduced
          • A greater burden of dependency
          • Average age of the labour force may increase and make it less mobile
          • Gender distribution may be influenced
          • A shortage of skilled workers
          • Under-utilisation of resources. The country may become under-populated

        • Advantages

          • Emigrations may send money home to help their relatives to increase the living standards

  • Causes of net migration

    • Relative living standards at home and abroad
    • Persecution of particular groups
    • Extent of control on the movement of people

Changes

In size

  • Optimum age

    • Definition: It is the size of the population which maximises the country’s output per head

    • The balance between population and resources is of crucial importance

    • Results

      • Under population

        • If it does not have enough of human resources to make the best use of its resources

      • Over population

        • If there is a shortage of land, capital and technical knowledge, relative to the number of workers

    • It is hard to determine optimum age because the quantity and quality of resources are changing all the time

  • Consequences of population growth

    • Advantages

      • If the population is below the optimum size, the country can make better use of its resource

      • Market size will increase. It is easier for firms to take advantages of economies of scale

      • Increase factor mobility. If the growth is caused by an increase in birth rate or immigration, these people are familiar with new ideas and methods. Also, costs of training reduce

      • Demand will increase so investment may be stimulated and new technology may be introduced

      • A rise in labour force

        • Net migration will bring in more workers
        • More children will increase labour force in the long run, but in short run it will increase dependency ratio

    • Disadvantages

      • Concerns about famine. If the country is suffering from overpopulated and low agricultural productivity, the risk of more dependents appears

      • Restrictions on improvements in living standards. Resources which could have been used to improve living standards may be devoted to the provision of necessities(OC)

      • Overcrowding. Put pressure on housing and social capital and cause traffic congestion

      • Environmental pressure. May damage to wildlife habitats, water shortages and the depletion of non-renewable resources

      • Pressure on employment opportunities.

        • If there is an increase in the number of people of working age who lack skills(immigration), the government may need to pay more for education and training
        • *Remember: Immigration does not cause employment.(The number of job is not fixed) Immigration will increase the supply of labour and AD, if there is no available job or they have better skills, unemployment may appear.

      • Balance of payment pressures. More dependants may results in a rise in imports and some products may need to be diverted from the export to the home market

  • Ways to reducing birth rate

    • Improve the educational and employment opportunities for women
    • Improve healthcare and nutrition to reduce infant mortality and birth rate
    • Set up pension and sickness insurance schemes to reduce the need for family support
    • Raising school leaving age to raise costs of having children
    • Reduce or stop any financial support it gives to families for each child and provide incentives for families who restrict the number of children
    • More extreme way is to make it illegal to have children above a specified number

In structure

  • Gender

    • Gender distribution indicates the number of males compared to the number of females
    • In most countries, more boys are born than girls

  • Age

    • Age distribution is the division of the population into different age groups

    • Image

      • Population pyramids

        • Population pyramids are a graphical representation of the age and gender distribution of a country’s population.

    • Results

      • Low-income countries tend to have a relatively larger proportion of their population in the younger age groups.
      • Wealthier countries tend to have an ageing population with a growing number of people in older age groups.

    • Ageing population

      • Causes

        • A fall in birth rate
        • A fall in death rate
        • Net emigration

      • Consequences

        • A rise in dependency ratio
        • A change in the labour force. Older workers may be geographically and occupationally less mobile. More experienced, reliable and patient.
        • Higher demand for healthcare
        • Greater need for welfare services
        • Rise in cost of state and private pensions
        • Change in the pattern of demand

      • Ways to coping

        • Raise tax burden on workers
        • Raise the retirement age to reduce costs of pension and increase tax revenue
        • Encourage or make it compulsory for workers to save for their retirement
        • Raise productivity of workers by means of education and training to raise taxes
        • Encourage the immigration of younger skilled workers by issuing more work permits

  • Area

    • Internal migration

      • Workers migrate from rural to urban to search for better jobs or higher incomes.

      • Consequences

        • Advantages

          • Migrants may supply growing industries and result in a better allocation of resources
          • Raise living standards in rural area due to a decrease in initial unemployment and money sent back

        • Disadvantages

          • If the most productive workers leave, agricultural productivity may fall
          • May not available jobs in urban areas
          • External costs including congesting

Dependency ratio

  • It is the proportion of the population that has to be supported by the labour force

  • Formula: number in dependent age groups/number in the labour force*100

  • Causes of increase

    • Higher birth rates which mainly occurs in less economically developed countries
    • A high school leaving age
    • Social changes such as workers entering the labour force at a later stage due to greater demand for higher education
    • More people choose early retirement

entry.title: Thinking on 25 Things You Need to Know About the Future
entry.content:
I was inspired by a book called 25 things you need to know about the future written by Christopher Barnatt to discuss several details about the future development.

According to the two part I have read, the author holds the opinion that the new technology can help us save and reuse resources in the future and the aim is to reduce loss of energy during production. However, from my point of view, I don’t deny the author’s opinion, but we may need to pay more attention to sustainable development, like reusing resources as much as possible, clean energy like hydrogen energy and less pollution caused during production and daily life. Reducing loss may be not useful in long run as the total resource we owning is invariable, unless we achieve to use the resource as efficiently as over a large proportion. By contrast, reusing resources can consider the resource we owning is unlimited because we can always reuse them if they are used in correct ways. In addition, clean energy and less pollution supplement each other. Clean energy can reduce the cost of cleaning pollution and the waste caused during coal-based production.

As Hegel says, ‘but what experience and history teach is this – that nations and governments have never learned anything from history or acted upon any lessons they might have drawn from it.’ He means people can never go into a same river. Because we are at different time and meeting different problems, it is hard for us to follow the lessons which the history taught us. Both the author and I are analysing the trends of development. No one can judge who is correct or who is wrong through the history. The only thing we can do is to leave the right to judge to time.

The third part of the book has a meaningful name which can be regarded as a paronomasia.

The name is Fuelling the Third Millennium. The first layer of meaning is to analyse new resources or new ways to transforming energy in the following years to play the role of fuel, just like the oil in the past two millennium, while the second is to give some support to help and encourage the third millennium become better and better.

This part made me to think about a question — why do people create new things? Or I can explain it as what makes people to keep working instead of remaining unchanged? I think the answer is that people always desire something new to make the life much better and easier or some bad situations drive people to change. These two conditions differ from each other apparently. The first situation is to act spontaneously, consciously and initiatively. Compared with the first one, the second one is acting passively. From my point of view, the first situation is better than the second one, as the people realise themselves and own a heart of getting stronger.

Sometimes, some problems appear and then we take action. This is also kind of acting passively. However, if we can converse the way which we consider the world from being asked or forced to do something into acting spontaneously to improve ourselves and make a little contribution to the whole world to complete our own value of life, the result will not as bad as acting passively. Some changes will happen.

During the process of developing, situations discussed above will happen, but not limited to this. We may fail, just as the author wrote in the book, for example several rockets exploded. The loss of people’s lives and equipments can not be ignored. Anyway, the failure has been caused. The only thing we can do is to learn something from the failure and consider why we failed and how to be better next time. This is the thing that all the scientists who are trying to develop new ways to conserve the energy are doing now. They learn from the experience from the elderly and use the knowledge to do more experiments. They may fail as the elderly. They keep trying instead of giving up easily.

The last two parts of the books talk about two topics. One is computer science and inorganic life, while the other is future medicine. Although the author highly praised and held high expectation in these two fields, I still think these two topics can both be regarded as Pandora’s Box.

I never doubt that the computer science and medicine can play a positive, irreplaceable and essential role in human beings’ development. By contrast, I am worrying whether we have abilities to control the intelligent creatures designed and created by us. I read a short science fiction novel t**he** Bookshop at the End of the Universe written by Jiang Bo. The novel tells a story that after hundreds of years, humans can learn knowledge by technology instead of studying and reading books. Everyone is almost under the computers’ control as we can not think and study. This is kind of horrible and unacceptable. However, the significance of science fiction novel is to predict one result of development.

After considering the result of development, moral philosophy should also be discussed. Can we regard robots as humans, if they can think independently? Can we regard the knowledge which we get in other ways instead of learning by ourselves as the knowledge we own? Should people live an infinite lifespan? Everything is beyond the knowledge we have at present. It still requires a long time to complete the system of moral philosophy. In my opinion, things in the future, even tomorrow, are uncertain. As a result, these two parts of the book can be looked upon as discussion about whether we are ready to develop new technology. This comes back to the first part we discussed about this book above and makes a logic circle which might be intricate nowadays.

I really like this book, although the author and I have different opinions in several point. Additionally, it still is definitely shocked that some predictions in the books have become reality. The author predicted that a kind of virus would spread all over the world someday. This came true in 2020 as everyone knows that COVID-19 spread almost every corner on the Earth.

In conclusion, I have finished read this small book which predicts future. In some ways, I think this book is more likely to be a prediction on future technology, than future. Many points in the book make sense. We can only see a small part of the development of AI, Internet, biotechnology, nanotechnology and quantum physics. There is still a long way for us to go to discover how to put these things into use.

Today, many people merely consider their own benefit instead of owning the awareness of developing together. The society is not equal. The wealth you have may be able to decide how long you can live and how fast your wealth will grow. Gaps between people will become larger and larger, as a result, the competition will be more and more drastic. From my point of view, the solution is hidden in social science.

Future is about technology, but is more than it. It is more about the human beings and the society, including humanitarian things and a variety of meaningful things needed to be considered by us.

entry.title: Section1 The Basic Economic Problems
entry.content:
The nature of the economic problem

Needs vs Wants

  • Needs are essential goods and services required for survival
  • Wants are goods and services that are not necessary for survival

Economics goods vs Free good

  • Economics goods have opportunity cost.
  • Definition: Economic goods is a product which requires resources to produce it and therefore has an opportunity cost. EG. carpet
  • Free goods don’t have opportunity cost.
  • Definition: Free goods is a product which dos not require any resources to make it and so does not have an opportunity cost. EG. sunshine, water in a river
    • If the water is processed for drinking or irrigation of fields, it becomes an economic goods.

Economic problem

  • Definition: The people’s wants are unlimited, but the resources are limited.( Scarcity )
  • Everyone has to make choices because of scarcity.

Opportunity cost

Resource allocation therefore involves deciding how best to use scarce resources to satisfy as many needs and wants as possible.

Definition: Opportunity cost is the cost of choice. It means the best alternative foregone when making a choice. It is the cost measured in terms of the next best choice given up when making a choice.

Production possibility curve

Definition: PPC shows the maximum combined output of two or more products a firm or an entire economy can produce with its available resources.

locations of points

  • on the curve

    • efficient
    • attainable

  • inside the curve

    • inefficient
    • attainable

  • outside the curve

    • unattainable

shift

  • outside

    • increase in resources
    • increase in productivity
    • improve technology

  • inside

    • decrease in the productive capacity( quantity or quality) of a country

PPCs are therefore a useful way of showing the opportunity cost of producing more of one product in terms of how much of another must be given up

Factors of production

LAND

[SYN] Natural Resources

  • Definition: Land is gifts of nature available for production. eg. land itself, coal, rainforests, fish
  • Renewable & Unrenewable
  • Rewards: Rent

LABOUR

[SYN] Human capital

  • Definition: Labour is the human effort used in producing goods and services.
  • Improved productivity—-Technology, education and training
  • Rewards: Wages

CAPITAL

  • Definition: Capital is human-made goods used in production. eg. offices, factories, machinery, railway and tools.

  • Capital goods vs Consumer goods

    • determine who is the user and the purpose of its use

  • Rewards: Interest

ENTERPRISE

  • Definition: Enterprise is the skill a business person required to combine and manage successfully the other three factors of production and ability to undertake risk and to make decisions in business. （Do not include managers)
  • Rewards: Profits

Mobility

  • Land

    • occupationally mobile
    • geographically immobile

  • Labour

    • occupationally immobile

      • lack of information
      • lack of appropriate skills and qualifications

    • geographically immobile

      • differences in the price and availability of housing in different areas and countries
      • family ties
      • differences in educational systems in different areas and countries
      • lack of information
      • restrictions on the movement of workers

  • Capital

    • varies according to the type of capital goods

  • Enterprise(Entrepreneurs)

    • Most mobile FOP

entry.title: Thinking on Tengnuo
entry.content:
Some thinking on Changing Position of a Great Country

It is a book written by Fan He which is the professor majored in Economics and Management. He has researched the government policies and measures, and the market for tens of years. This is the fourth book in his series which aims at recording 30 years of the economic development of China.

This book is talking about the changing position called Tengnuo in Chinese which is recognised as the future solution of all kinds of problems especially during the competition.

What is *tengnuo*?

It is about when facing problems, we can change our way of thinking and generate another method to contribute to a positive result. When I first got this concept, I thought this is some how similar to the sayings told by my Chinese teacher in junior high school. It is quoted from a song which has the lyrics of “These is a crack in everything, that’s how the light gets in”. He also said, “Please remember to find the positive point when you face serious problems and even make some mistakes.”

However, after thinking twice, I found some differences between them. My teacher aims at the mental position of us which means we need to think more positively and provide ourselves with some satisfying words. However, tengnuo is the following step after thinking which is the action. It tells us to take future action.

Firstly, we need to find a breaking point because the competition is never carried out in one dimension. As a result, concentrating all the advantaged resources in one point can provide us with chance to compete with the competitors. Additionally, it is also important to pay more attention to ourselves instead of being influenced by others. Finally, the condition which limits us should be changed. The time, for example, can be used to balance problems. We do not need to solve all the problems in a specific time. By contrast, it will be more proper to make the time more elastic and find new opportunities.

Tengnuo\ and country

Nowadays, China is facing thousands of problems, such as the ageing population, the lack of people in rural areas and the announcement of a variety of policies.

We can employ tengnuo to solve these problems. For example, the ageing population which is always seen as the problem or the drawback of the whole society. However, if we concentrate in researching and developing new products specially designed for the elderly. This is kind of tengnuo, because we are generating the risks into opportunities instead of complaining it all the time, doing nothing and being afraid of it.

Tengnuo\ and my life

This is a significant part of controlling and directing an organisation. When studying the Human Resource Management in Business Studies, we learnt about the method of creating motivation of the employees. I started to understand that the basics of motivating employees. With the help of the concept tengnuo, I can understand it better now. Many HRs use the method of increasing the salary or wages of the employees. However, thousand of the psychologists and economists spent time learning non-financial factors such as the Scientific Management Method by Taylor, Expectation Theory by Vroom and Hierarchy of Human Need by Herzberg. This is a kind of tengnuo, as these scientists found that the money sometimes could not incentive the employees. Thus they started to pay attention to other aspects.

Conclusion

Tengnuo will always be one of the most useful methods during problem solving because this is another way of thinking and analysing for both the individuals and the whole economy.

entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter1 What is economics & Why does it matter?
entry.content:
Extract

PartA Economics Defined

  • What do economists do? A simple answer is that economists practice, teach, or work to advance the field of economics.
  • Every person who chooses finance or accounting as a college major is also required to duty economics, but economics isn’t the same as finance or accounting. Economics is the framework that underlies all the business disciplines, just as physics is the framework that underlies all the engineering disciplines.
  • What interests an economist is how human beings behave when they get their hands on a pile of money. In other words, economics is about human behaviour.
  • We might say that economics is the social science concerned with how people (or other decision-making units such as business firms or government agencies) can best allocate their limited resources to achieve optimal or maximum satisfaction. Or, we could say that economics deals with how people make choices in conditions of scarcity.

PartB Economic Resources

  • Most modern economists start from the assumption that having more material goods is better than having fewer material goods. Thus the more-is-better paradigm is fundamental to economics, although it is sometimes questioned and even criticised.
  • Economic resources are generally divided into four categories: land, labour, capital, and entrepreneurship.
    • Land includes any natural asset that may be used in producing goods and services.
    • Labour is exactly workers along with their skills and abilities. The resource category of labour also has a connection with the term human capital, which refers to workers’ skills, experience, and education.
    • Capital includes all goods produced in support of the production of other goods.
    • Entrepreneurs assemble material resources and determine reduction and distribution. They are innovators who dream up new products, create new twists to old products, and open new markets for established products. They also assume the risk of failure inherent in any business endeavour.
  • When the stock of resources increases, or when the quality of resources improves, the result is economics growth.

PartC Schools and Subfields of Economics

  • No one is coordinating all this activity. It is all occurring as if it were being guided by an unseen power. This power is what Adam Smith called the market’s “invisible hand,” and what modern economists recognise as market forces.
  • Major schools of economics thought
    • Classical school
      • The economy operates best when markets are mostly left to their own devices — when the government employs a liaises-faire, or hands-off, approach.
      • Prices (also known as the price mechanism) allocate resource efficiently, as if all economic activity were being guided by an invisible hand.
      • Advocate free trade, specialisation, and the division of labour.
      • There was little or no role for the government in managing the economy.
    • Marxist school
      • Capital is will one day be replaced by socialism and then, later on, by communism.
      • Labour theory of value — It states that the value of a good derives from the labour required to produce it.
      • Marxists favour the notion of tightly controlled markets or no markets at all.
    • Neoclassical school
      • Built on the proposition of Classical economics and began to focus on some of the finer details of interactions in markets.
      • The neoclassical view begins with the assumption that people are basically rational when they make decisions.
      • Neoclassicals believe that consumers behave rationally and attempt to maximise their utility, or satisfaction, within the limits of their available resources. Sellers, also assumed to be acting rationally, are seen as attempting to maximise their profits.
      • The focus on comparing additional costs and additional benefits, or marginal analysis are emerged from the Neoclassical school.
    • Keynesian school
      • He agreed with a number of basic tenets of Classical economics. But he also disagreed with certain Classical ideas such as the notion that unemployment is self-correcting, or the belief that government has no significant role to play in correcting the economic problems of a nation, state, or region.
      • Keynes and his disciples believed that government has the means, as well as the moral obligation to counteract problems such as unemployment and inflation through its taxing and spending policies.
    • Austrian school
      • The Austrian school of economic thought is related to the Neoclassical school and sometimes even seen as a subcomponent of that school.
      • As believers in and defenders of free markets, the Austrians are vehemently opposed to government involvement in the economy.
    • New institutional school
      • The New Institutional school of economic thought is another extension of Neoclassical economics.
      • One important idea that emerged from New Institutional economics in the concept of transaction costs, or the extra costs involved in the completion of a transaction. These include the costs associated with searching for products, negotiating terms, and enforcing agreements.
    • Monetarist school
      • Monetarism is another school of economic thought that argues for free markets.
      • It maintains that, in the short term, the economy’s output, or gross domestic product (GDP) is primarily determined by the money supply, or the total amount of money in circulation. Over the longer periods (or what economist typically refer to as “the long run”) the key determinant of the current-dollar GDP is the overall prices in the economy.
    • Behaviouralist school
      • Behavioural economics, broadly speaking, borrows certain concepts and ideas from psychology and overlaps to some degree with that field.
      • Through carefully designed laboratory experiments and other forms of research, behavioural economists have identified situations in which people are systematically irrational.
      • Behavioural economics includes several different strands such as psychological economics, experimental economics, and behavioural finance.

Personal thinkings

This chapter mainly focuses on the most basic concepts in Economics, such as the factors of production and scarcity. Additionally, it introduces some major schools of economics thought including behaviouralist school, monetarist school, new institutional school, Austrian school, Keynesian school, Neoclassical school, Marxist school, and Classical school.

When I was reading the part for classification of schools, it was surprising that many of them occur in both IGCSE and A-Level textbooks without being mentioned the type of school. For example, I have never learnt it before that it was Neoclassical economists who argued that customers behaved rationally during purchasing. During the process of introducing all these major school, I started to understand that Economics is never only being black or white which means if we can explain it with our own words or with the support of data, we can say that our conclusion makes sense.

However, generating this understanding is much more difficult than just knowing it from the aspect of ration. When reading the Marxist school, I found it hard for me to criticise its sayings.

There is one sentence in the chapter which I really appreciate and love, saying, “Even Nobel laureates in economics sharply disagree with one another. That’s one reason why you, as an informed citizen, should have a basic understanding of what’s at stake in those disagreements, so that you can listen to both sides and arrive at your own conclusions.” The values of UWC (United World College) include “celebration of different”. From my point of view, this can be applied in the study and research of Economics as well.

entry.title: Thinking on The Fuzzy and The Techie
entry.content:
This book mainly talks about the relationship between the Liberal Arts and digital world.

What is the Liberal Arts? Liberal arts generally covers four areas including the natural sciences, social sciences, arts and humanities. At present, there are some liberal arts colleges in the U.S.A. which are undergraduate institutions of high education, for example the Wellesley College. From my point of view, liberal arts plays an essential role in our society. First of all, liberal arts can also be described as “psychology”. All the liberal arts majors aim to research the way in which humans consider things and the influence on the society caused by these consideration. From example, Economics is the study which looks for the mentality of the consumers, producers and governments in a specific market. In addition, liberal arts also represents interdisciplinary study and research. A liberal arts education encourages students to integrates different areas of study, making students to explore a variety of subjects. This results in students can consider one problem from multiple perspectives.

What is STEM? STEM stands for science, technology, engineering and maths. These subjects promote the development of technology which has a wider meaning than the technology in STEM. This will result in a better living standard. For example, it is possible for us to print a house in a relative short time with a 3D printer which requires a long time with plenty of workers to finish.

I must point out that STEM and liberal arts coincide in some areas. For example, they both cover the natural science which include chemistry, physics and other subjects.

The first thing I want to talk about is the interdisciplinary studies. This is defined as the combination of two or more academic disciplines into one activity. When it happens, something is created by thinking across boundaries between different subjects. At present, a variety of interdisciplinary studies appears in our society for example the PPE ( Politics, Philosophy and Economics) and HSPS (Human, Social, and Political Sciences). During interdisciplinary studies, students can easily develop the skills of critical thinking, communication, creative problem solving, self-expression, innovative research and lifelong learning. This can promote the digital worlds as when we start an Internet company, everything needs to be considered detailedly without any mistakes. These skills will work. I still remembered the words which were said by my junior high school head teacher Mr. Cao. He said that in the future, we needed to concentrate in one areas to be more professional, because this could help us avoid being replaced by others. With the development of technology, the main problem has turned from replacement by the other workers to replacement by the technology. The times changed. From my point of view, overuse of technology may result in an increase in unemployment. Unskilled people may find it more and more difficult to earn a living. Skilled people must be more and more professional to keep their job. However, liberal arts can solve this problem in some ways. entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter2 Thinking like an economist
entry.content:
Extract

  • Some economic thinking coincides with what many people call “common sense”. But other theories, principles, and findings fro the field of economics strike the average person as counterintuitive.

PartA Fundamental Economic Concepts

  • Incentives
    • Although the idea that incentives matter may seem obvious, a lot of smart people are unclear on the concept. But actions have consequences.
    • Rules and operating procedures are a necessary component of responsible governing. But government policymakers and business managers who are thinking about implementing a new measure should make sure you’ve considered the potential changes in incentive structures. If they fail to think the issue through, they’ll learn about the unintended consequences the hard way.
  • Opportunity costs
    • This concept separates the economists from the accountants.
    • A situation may present more than two options, of course; in fact, there may be thousands of options from which to choose. But in any situation where only one option can be chosen, the forfeited value of the best option that is not chosen is the costs of that choice — its opportunity cost.
    • Opportunity costs aren’t always easy to quantify.
  • Cost-benefit analysis
    • Economists are experts in assigning monetary value to things that don’t ordinarily have dollar signs attached to them.
    • As the term implies, cost-benefit analysis involves comparing the cost of a given action with the benefit (value) of that action.
    • Economists have also developed a number of methods for assigning dollar values to forests, rivers, clean air, and the like.
    • An economist will also consider the forest’s no use value, which is the value it holds for people who will never use the first for any activity or harvest its trees for any purpose.
    • As we consume more and more units of a particular good over a given period of time, the benefit, or utility, we derive from that good tends to fall with each successive unit that we consume. This is the principle of diminishing marginal utility.
  • Sunk costs
    • Economic theory suggests that if a sunk cost you’ve already incurred constitutes one element of a decision that you’re facing, you should ignore the sunk cost and focus instead on the costs and benefits you’ll face as you go forward. Your attention should be on your future marginal costs and marginal benefits, not on your sunk costs.
  • Rational behaviour and types of preferences
    • Assuming rational behaviour means that an economist will see people as generally making choices that will produce the most benefit to themselves.
    • There’s often a gap between what people say they like (stated preferences) and the preferences they express when forced to make a real choice (revealed preferences).
    • When someone’s choices reflect the order of his conscious preferences, someone is exhibiting transitive preferences, which are assumed to underlie rational decision making.
    • Incidentally, economist have conducted experiments showing that children are much less likely than adults to exhibit transitive preferences; for this reason, children are not always rational in their decision making and may need help from adults.
  • Purposeful behaviour, bounded rationality, behavioural economics, and biases
    • Our process was rational within certain limits, and an economist would see it as an example of bounded rationality.
    • One particular sub field of economics, behavioural economics, has she Ishtar on situations in which people are, so to speak, predictably irrational.
    • Behavioural economics also has a lot to say about certain tendencies that affect decision making and are known collectively as cognitive biases.
      • Gambler’s fallacy
      • Confirmation bias — People have a tendency to seek out information that they already agree with. We know what we want, we know what we like, and confirmation bias sends us out into the world, physically or virtually, in search of exactly those things.
      • Anchoring effect — It comes up in many decision-making contexts where people exhibit a tendency to lock on to the first piece of information they receive.
      • Status quo bias — It is the tendency to preserve the current state of affairs.
      • Endowment effect — The human tendency to stick with the status quo is the power behind the bias known as the endowment effect. People under the influence of this cognitive bias place more value n goods if they happen to own them than they would if they didn’t own those goods.

PartB Fundamental Economic Models and Assumptions

  • A model, of course, is a small-scale version of something bigger.
  • An economist’s model of the economy and its various aspects is a small-scale version that can’t hope to capture everything going on in the actual economy.
  • Many (though not all) economic forecasting models assume that future events are more or less predictable based on event that have already occurred.
  • Economic forecasting models are still useful, however, even though unforeseen events can and sometimes do prove their basic assumptions false.
  • Every economic model has to start from some type of assumption. A given model may incorporate its own particular set of assumptions, but some assumptions tend to be common to a variety of economic models.
  • Every economic model starts with at least some kind of generalisation.
  • Another assumption commonly used in economic models is that of coteries paribus, which is Latin for “all other things being equal.”
  • Wherever you come down on the question of nudges from the government, you have to acknowledge that government has learned its tactics from the experts — the many businesses that use advertising to nudge their customers into buying more of their products.

Personal thinkings

Economics does influence people’s way of analysing problems and events in our daily life.

I still remember that, by the end of Senior 1, when choosing the subjects for the future two years, I employed the concept “opportunity costs” which is introduced in this chapter. I knew that if I had not learnt Economics, I would not have been thinking in such a way. This is the treasure of Economics similar with mentioned in the chapter “Although you may not be thinking totally like an economist by the end of the chapter, you’ll hopefully gain some understanding about why economists see the would the way they do and why that’s actually a good thing.”

Another interesting point of Economics is that it is the study of human behaviour. However, it is also based on a huge quantity of assumptions including but not limited to, ceteris paribus, and generalisation. No one, neither all the human being group, can be simplified using a simple model with the help of several assumption. But the economists did achieve to simplify several aspects. This is kind of conflict. We can not know whether these research results are correct because none of the correctness of these can be tested. The only thing we can do is to explain them with our personal understanding.

Still, when I was just a little kid, I started to believe that the happiness of a person or the satisfaction can not be quantified, but economists achieved it again.

To sum up, Economics brings me exactly a new way of thinking and a new way of understanding the world. When choosing the subjects as I mentioned above, once I said, “Choosing subjects is not about the subject itself, but more about choosing a way of understanding the world. It is possible for me to get high marks in Business or Chemistry. However, my final choice will always be Business because I really prefer the way which is provided by Business.”
