entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter5 Globalisation & the US economy
entry.content:
Extract

PartA What is globalisation, and What is good about it?

  • Globalisation is the process by which markets become integrated among nations. Aspects of globalisation include international trade, foreign investment, and labour migration.
  • One reason why people engaged in international trade in centuries past was that hey wanted goods that weren’t available in their homelands.
  • The primary reason why countries continue to exchange goods and services is that they stand to gain a lot from specialisation and trade.
  • Globalisation and the concept of advantage
    • Absolute advantage
      • In economics, a country is said to have an absolute advantage in producing a particular good if it can do so at a lower absolute cost, or per-unit cost, than a trading partner can.
    • Comparative advantage
      • David Ricardo, a British economist who lived in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, introduced the principle of comparative advantage.
      • A country has a comparative advantage in producing a particular good when that country can product the good at a lower opportunity cost than a trading partner can.
    • A particular country may not have an absolute advantage in reducing any one good, but every country has a comparative advantage over potential trading partners in producing some good.
    • Without international trade many of the goods we purchase on a regular basis would be more expensive. Free international trade has proven so beneficial that the majority of nations in the world have entered into free trade agreements with other nations.
  • Globalisation and multinational corporations
    • Another important aspect of globalisation has been the spread of the multinational corporation, which is a firm that operates and owns assets in more than one country.
  • Globalisation and currency valuations
    • The foreign exchange market is where the currencies of the various nations are traded.
    • There was a time when most of the world’s currencies were pegged to gold. Later, for a period of time after World War II, the United States pegged the dollar to gold, and most other countries pegged their currencies to dollar.
    • Nowadays, sot currency values float freely, which means that their value is constantly changing in relation to other currencies.
    • Trade barriers
      • Tariff is a tax that an importer has on imported goods.
      • Import quotas are limits on the amount of a good that can be imported.
      • Voluntary export restraints (VERs) are similar to import quotas with respect to their economic impart, but they’re not exactly imposed by the importing country.
      • Quality restrictions are restrictions based on the quality of goods to be imported.
      • Government subsidies to the domestic producers of a good.
      • An embargo, typically imposed for political reasons and not for the purpose of protecting domestic firms and industries, is a complete ban on trade with a particular nation.

PartB Free trade agreements and other forms of economic integration

  • A free trade agreement is an arrangement among two or more nations to form what’s known as a free trade area.
    • The participating countries agree to reduce or eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers on the goods that they trade among themselves while keeping trade barriers in place with countries that aren’t parties to the agreement.
    • Example: Latin American Integration Association, South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement, and North American Free Trade Agreement
      • Customer unions are like free trade agreements, but the participating countries also agree to adopt a common external tariff.
      • Common markets feature even greater integration as well as free movement of capital and labour across international borders.
      • Economic unions include all the integration involved in common markets in addition to unity where certain economic policies are concerned.

PartC Protectionism: the flip side of free trade

  • Sometimes free trade is restricted for geopolitical reasons. One country may choose not to trade with another because the two nations are political enemies.
  • Some trade barriers exist because a country wants to preserve a certain aspect of its cultural identity, which mean that it doesn’t want foreign products — and, by extension, foreign culture — to overtake its own culture.
  • Most trade barriers are erected because of political pressure from domestic producers who want to lessen competition from foreign producers.
    • Infant industries
    • national defence
    • Retaliation
    • Employment rate

PartD Possible downsides of globalisation

  • As we’ve seen, when trade opens up across borders, there are bound to be winners and losers in the domestic economy. But as economic theory suggest, and as most economists agree, the total benefit for the domestic economy is likely to be greater than the total cost.
  • Promotion of income inequality
    • Economic theory suggest that international trade should have an equalising effect on income over time, but empirical studies have produced mixed results.
    • It seems likely that the question of whether globalisation promotes economic equality or inequality will depend on the countries doing the trading and on the sorts of goods they are trading.
  • Corporate tax evasion
    • Capital, whether financial capital or physical capital, tends to move to where it will bring the highest returns, and lower taxes generally imply higher returns.
  • Abuse of weaker nations by more powerful nations
    • When abuses do occurs, they do so under the guise of regular international trade. But, just as trade barriers are not the best way to deal with forced labour and other abuses of human rights, it’s better to establish policies that target specific abuses of weaker nations by stronger ones, rather than attempting to tackle such abuse though broad protectionist policies that oppose globalisation as a whole.
  • Homogenisation of national cultures
    • The fear that local cultures will dissipate or disappear is not unfounded, but it ha to be balanced against the benefits that societies gain from the cultural cross-pollination that has accompanies globalisation.

PartE The economics of immigration

  • Immigration does not appear to harm the economy, and in some ways it actually helps it.
  • In addition to boosting economic output and employment, immigration also helps the economy in another important way. Our native-born labour force has been shrinking — and will continue to shrink — relative to the number of retirees receiving Social Security benefits.
  • The economic benefits of globalisation are too great and will continue to be vast. There’s no doubt that as communication and transportation continue to become cheaper and faster, and as the cultures of the world continue to blend together, the world will just keep growing smaller and smaller.

Personal thinking

I still remember that for the first time to learn about the international trade and the concept of absolute and comparative advantages, I found it difficult to understand why most countries follow comparative advantages instead of absolute advantage. After reading this chapter, some of the doubts have been solved. However, new questions come to my mind.

We all know that globalisation generates great benefits to the nations, especially when countries all specialise in the production which they have comparative advantages. However, why some countries still impose protectionism. I know that maybe the national defence and infant industry can be problems, but based on the theory of utility, they can not maximise the utility. As a result, is the government rational when making such decisions and announcing these policies?

These questions are hard to be solved because the actual utility can hardly be measured quantitively using the money as the unit. It is mentioned previously that the work of economist is to quantify these quantities, so I believe that these questions can be solved in the future or maybe have been solved but I don’t know that.

entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter3 Free markets versus government regulation
entry.content:
Extract

PartA The miracle of markets

  • You could say that markets are one of humanity’s most amazing inventions — but that wouldn’t be quite accurate. A free market is truly amazing, and yet it’s not exactly an invention. It is simply a form of human interaction, a means for people to experts their tastes, have their wants and needs met, and earn their livelihoods by serving their fellow human beings.
  • A market is an institution or medium that connects potential buyers with potential sellers.
  • Demand is simply the consumer’s need or desire for a good or a service.
  • This basic notion — that people tend to want more of a good at a lower price and less of the good at a higher price — is embodied in a fundamental principle in economics known as the law of demand.
  • The law of supply says that when the price of a good rises, sellers are willing to provide greater quantities of the good, and that when the price falls, sellers are willing to provide less of the good.
  • Demand and supply gravitate toward a point, called the equilibrium, where the quantity of a good that sellers are willing to provide is the same as the quantity of the good that consumers want to purchase.
  • Each time there’s a change in the forces that underlie demand or supply, the market responds and a new equilibrium is reached. No individual or centralised agency coordinates any of this activity, and no one needs to. It occurs naturally as an outgrowth of human interaction.

PartB Market failure and market regulation

  • Markets are amazing and beautiful when they work well, and in most instances, they work very well indeed. When they don’t, we have what economists refer to as market failure, a situation in which a market, left to its own devices, produces either more or less than the socially optimal amount of a good or a service.
  • Causes of market failure — Most commonly because of poor or incomplete information, lack of competition, or the presence of external costs or benefits.
    • Poor or incomplete information
      • Typically in such a case, one party to a transaction will have more information than the other party. In a situation like this one, economists say there is asymmetric information.
    • Lack of competition
      • The outcome is not socially optimal in these scenarios, because the market fails to attract potential consumers who would be willing to buy the product or service if it were competitively priced.
    • External costs and benefits — Positive and negative externalities
      • A particular type of market failure has to do with what is called a public good. The key characteristic of a public good is that it can’t easily be divided, and so people can’t easily be prevented from enjoying its benefits.
  • The need for regulation
  • Market failure versus failure of market outcomes
    • Nothing reveals human tastes as well as markets do; you can ask people what they like, but you won’t get nearly as honest an answer as when you observe that they’re actually buying.
    • Markets are completely nonjudgmental. They have no morality built into them. That’s one reason why a government may decide to regulate a market: the market’s activity doesn’t conform to acceptable social standards.
    • An important thing to keep in mind, however, is that social standards and notions of morality and ethics can tend to change over time.

PartC Price controls as an example of government regulation

  • A price ceiling is a maximum price allowed by law, and a price floor is a minimum price required by law.
  • Price ceilings
    • When a price ceiling has been established, sellers are not allowed to charge more for a particular good than the price set by the government. The problem with price ceilings is that they change the incentives in a market.
  • Price floors
    • When a price floor is in effect, the government requires sellers to charge buyers a specified minimum amount for a good or service. Like a price ceiling, a price floor changes incentives in ways that distort the market. As experience shows, a price floor may come with other unintended consequences.
    • The minimum wage
    • The living wage
    • Agricultural price supports

PartD Government failure

  • If a market failure occurs, the government’s intervention may be justified. But it’s also true that the government doesn’t always offer the best solution. Politicians and bureaucrats may end up making things worse or even creating a whole new problem — a situation known as government failure.
  • There’s no one-size-fits-all approach to determining when there’s an economic basis for government intervention in a failed market, so it’s wise for officials to examine the costs and benefits of sitting the failure out, versus intervening to solve the problem.
  • Of course, estimating the costs and benefits of proposed regulation is complicated, time-consuming, and potentially controversial task — exactly the kind of task that will keep economists employed in this country for a long time to come.

Personal thinking

Most of the things in this chapter have been taught in IGCSE or A-Level Economics.

This is an important part in Microeconomics including the demand and supply, the equilibrium price, market failure which I think can be regarded as the drawbacks of market economy, and government failure which I think can be regarded as the drawbacks of the planned economy or the government intervention.

Comparing the free market and the market with government intervention, they share a similar characteristic which is suffering from possible problems which means no matter which market it is, it is always probable for the society does not enjoy the society optimal

PartA Competitive versus non competitive markets

  • A market or industry characterised by perfect competition has so many sellers of a good or s
  • The products in a perfectly competition environment market, and even ini a market that is highly if not perfectly competitive, tend to be standardised.
  • If a firm is the only seller of a particular good or service, the firm is said to have a pure monopoly on that good or service.
  • A market can also be an oligopoly, one that consists of a few large firms or is dominated by a few large firms.

PartB Monopolies

  • One barrier to entry is when it’s most efficient for a single firm to supply an entire market. In this situation, the firm is said to have a natural monopoly.
  • Another type of barrier is a resource monopoly, with a single firm controlling all access to a necessary input.
  • Common misconceptions about monopolies
    • One misconception is that monopoly firms are guaranteed high profits.
      • It’s true, of course, that if a company has a market monopolised, the company stands to earn a much higher profit than it would if the market were competitive.
      • It’s also possible for a company to have a monopoly on a product or service for which there isn’t enough demand to generate a profit.
    • Another misconception is that a monopolist necessarily charges the very highest possible price for its product or service.
      • Because this monopoly firm wants to maximise its profit, it can’t charge the highest price that a tiny minority of its customers would be willing to pay. If it did, it would lose the vast majority of the market. The firm’s customers would simply find other alternatives.
    • One of the biggest misconceptions about monopolies is that they’re always bad.
      • But the fact is that many monopolies create extraordinary value, not just for stockholders, managers, and employees, but for society as a whole.
      • Besides, some products might never have become available at all if their inventors and developers hadn’t been granted patents and monopoly power for long enough to recoup the costs of research and development.
  • Identifying monopolies
    • There are measures that economists can use to determine how competitive an industry is. The two principle measures are concentration ratios and the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index(HHI).
    • “Four-firm concentration ratio”
      • When the ‘four-firm concentration ratio’ of an industry is calculated, the result shows the market share of the four largest firms in an industry as a proportion of the industry’s total sales.
    • HHI
      • The HHI’s potential values may be as low as nearly zero (for a very highly competitive industry) and as high as 10000 (for an industry whose market is limited to one seller, a purely monopolistic scenario).
      • If a proposed merger is a highly concentrated market seemed likely to increase the HHI by more than 200 points, then the merger might face government opposition on the grounds that it would unduly decrease competition if allowed to proceed.
    • We’ve seen that every firm in an oligopolistic market is extremely sensitive to the effects of the actions taken by the other firms in that market.
    • A group of businesses engaged in collusion is commonly referred to as a cartel.
  • Monopolistic competitions
    • The monopolistic competition does enjoy a monopoly, but only when it comes to its own brand; in contrast to the pure monopolist, and there are close substitutes for the monopolistic competitor’s product.
    • A monopolistic competitor’s goal is to convince consumers that there really are no close substitutes for its product, even though that’s actually not the case.

PartC Antitrust regulation and enforcement

  • The government has long sought both to regulate firms that have monopoly power and, at times, to restrict the formation of monopolies in the first place.
  • The economic justification for regulating a monopoly is that monopolistic practices tend to create higher prices and lower levels of output than would exist in a competitive market, and such outcomes aren’t socially optimal.
  • Review of mergers and acquisitions
    • One of the primary ways for the government to limit the formation of monopolies is to review proposed mergers and not allow some of them to go through.
    • Merger cases can become very political.
    • The fact that some administrations have allowed mergers that probably would have failed under other administrations implies that a certain amount of discretion exists in the enforcement of antitrust laws.
  • Price-based antitrust regulation
    • The government may choose to regulate a monopoly firm by imposing a price ceiling with the aim of achieving a market price close or equal to the price that would prevail in a competitive market.
    • In a highly concentrated market, however, it’s hard to get a price ceiling right because they must gauge what the competitive price would be in a market that has never been truly competitive.
    • Government regulators may also prevent a dominant firm from engaging in certain kinds of anticompetitive behaviour such as predatory pricing, or the practice of setting a very low price, often below the cost of producing a good, so as to har a competitor.
  • Breakup of monopolies

Personal thinking

At the beginning of this chapter, the author discussed several forms of market structures and then mentioned the misconception of monopoly, followed by a variety of forms of antitrust actions. Before reading this, I have never learn the antitrust acts so detailedly and structurally.

Some of the people in our world believe that the monopoly is bad or even evil. However, in fact, these monopolies do play important roles in the market and generate benefits to the whole society. We never deny that monopoly power brings problems such as a low degree of competition, a relatively high price, fewer choices, and the over reliance on certain companies. It is kind of critical thinking that it both has positive impacts and negative outcomes.

However, although there are great positive impacts creating by the monopolies, the governments all around the world are still trying to imposing regulations and laws to prevent some actions and even reduce the existence of monopoly. This is because the economists, the governments, the monopolistic companies, the customers and other stakeholders holds different views, all of who argue for their benefits or the benefits of the most people. This is acceptable after all.

entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter6 Understanding the macroeconomic news
entry.content:
Extract

PartA Macroeconomics and Microeconomics

  • When economists talk about macroeconomics or the macroeconomy, they’re referring to the economy as a whole or to the economy’s larger sectors. These latter include the public sector and the private sector, which in turn is sometimes subdivided into the business sector and the private sector.
  • When economists talk about microeconomics or the macroeconomy, they’re referring to specific industries or to individual decision-making units, such as consumers, firms, or government agencies.
  • It’s not always easy to draw the line between macroeconomic and microeconomic issues.

PartB Indicators of economic health

  • Rate of economic growth
    • Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
      • GDP can be thought of as the total spending in the economy on domestically produced goods and services.
      • Whereas GDP focuses on where production is taking place, GNP (Gross National Product) focuses on the citizenship of the people who are the owners of the factors involved in production.
      • When the national income accountants at the Bureau of Economic Analysis calculate the rate of economic growth, they have to be careful to use real GDP rather than nominal GDP in their calculation.
      • Real GDP is adjusted for inflation — or, to put it more broadly, real GDP is adjusted for changes in the nation’s price levels.
      • GDP divided by the population is known as per capita GDP, and it’s an especially handy measure for comparing the economy of one nation to that of another.
      • Arguments against using GDP as a measure of the nation’s economic health
        • GDP accounts only for output, not for the input required to generate than output
        • GDP includes economic activity surrounding many negative events
        • GDP includes activity that involves human pain and suffering apparat from the effects of natural disasters or social unrest
        • GDP doesn’t account for the value of nonmarket labour
        • GDP doesn’t account for changes in the quality of products
        • GDP is not a good measure of a nation’s level of well-being and happiness
    • Leading Economic Index
      • A complete discussion of all the economic indicators in use would take up an entire book, but one of them, the Conference Board’s Leading Economics Index (LEI) deserves mention because it includes a lot of valuable underlying information and can be useful in predicting economic upturns and downturns.
      • The 10 key variables that the LEI tracks tend to reveal coming trends earlier than the variables that other economic indicators are watching.
      • On average, the LEI does a better job of predicting future economic conditions than any of its 10 underlying variables does on its own.
    • The Almighty Dow
      • The Dow Jones Industrial Average, commonly referred to simply as the Dow, is a widely reported stock market index that was created in 1896 by Charles Dow, a Wall Street Journal editor and cofounder of Dow Jones & Company.
      • The Dow tracks the price movements of the stocks of 30 large, publicly traded US operations. It’s not a straight-up average of stock prices, but when the stock prices of the 30 companies rise on average, the Dow also rises.
      • The Dow is intended to give investors and market watchers an overview of market conditions and trends, but it’s not without its critics, of course. Some people contend that, given the roughly 10000 publicly traded companies in the country, the Dow uses too small a sample to provide an accurate reading of market trends.
  • Unemployment rate
    • It’s a true measure of well-being and provides some indication about what’s really happening on the ground.
    • The unemployment rate is different for people of different racial and ethnic groups, age groups, education levels, and employment types.
    • Bear in mind when you run across the unemployment rate in the press that it’s a national average, and so it may not reflect what’s happening with employment in the area where you live.
    • Also remember that the unemployment rate, because of the shortcomings in how it’s calculated, may not capture the true amount of labour underutilisation that’s occurring in your town or in the nation as a whole.
  • Rate of inflation
    • Inflation is a sustained rise in a nation’s overall price level for goods and services.
    • Inflation can become a serious problem in any economy
      • Inflation harms people who live on fixed incomes, such as income form a pension that doesn’t include a cost-of-living adjustment
      • Inflation penalises savers whose methods of investment aren’t indexed to inflation
      • Inflation harms lenders who haven’t accurately factored inflation into the loans they’ve granted
    • the real threat of inflation is that, left unchecked, it can get out of hand and lead to a rapidly accelerating inflation spiral known as hyperinflation. When hyperinflation occurs in a country, the monetary system typically breaks down.
    • Measurement of inflation
      • The inflation rate is calculated as the rate of change in a price index, which represents an average of prices for multitudes of goods and services in an economy.
        • Consumer price index (CPI)
        • Producer price index (PPI)
    • If prices can go up, can they come down?
      • A drop in overall prices is known as inflation
      • Typically, prices fall because demand for goods and services is also falling. When goods begin piling up in warehouses, sellers have no choice but to lower prices to move the merchandise.
      • Deflation can also complicate things in a shrinking economy.
  • Interest rate
    • Interest is the charge paid to a bank or other lends for borrowed money — usually a certain percentage of the amount borrowed. In other words, the interest rate is the price of money.
    • There are many different types of interest rates in the economy.
      • Prime leading rate, which is the interest rate that banks charge their most creditworthy customers
      • Federal funds rate, which is the interest rate that US banks pay each other for overnight loans

PartC Monetary policy, fiscal policy and the federal reserve

  • Monetary policy, fiscal policy, and the federal reserve
    • Monetary and fiscal policy
      • Monetary policy is the set of actions taken by a central bank to regulate the size and growth of a nation’s money supply.
      • In the United States, the federal government plays a role in managing the economy and influencing the macroeconomy thought its fiscal policy. The government tools of fiscal policy come down to two basic elements: taxes and expenditures.
    • Federal reserve
      • In the United States, the central bank is known as the Federal Reserve, and it’s often referred to as “the Fed”.
      • The history and structure of the Federal Reserve
        • The Federal Reserve structure represents a compromise between those who wanted a strong central bank and those who feared its development.
        • One aspect of the compromise is that the bank wasn’t set up as one large institution but rather as 12 main Federal Reserve banks distributed throughout the country.
      • The Fed and monetary policy
        • One of the Fed’s jobs is to manage the nation’s monetary policy.
        • The Federal Reserve has three basic tools of monetary policy at its disposal. In other words, it has three different approaches available for managing the money supply
          • Discount rate
            • Since the Fed acts as a bankers’ bank, it offers loans to banks in need of reserves. The interest rate that the agency charges on such loans is know as the discount rate.
          • Required reserve ratio
            • All banks are required to keep a portion of their outstanding deposits in reserve, and banks that are members of the Federal Reserve System keep some of those reserves on hand at the Fed.
          • Open market operations
          • The Fed engages in open market operations — that is, the Fed buys and sells government securities on the open market, such as US Treasury bonds and other instruments that the government uses to finance its operations.
        • The Fed and interest rate

Personal thinking

This chapter mentions about the macroeconomic concepts such as GDP, price indices and interest rate. The way of introducing such concepts differs from that of the textbooks of IGCSE and A-Level.

This book introduces the measures of economic health which is the same between the two sets of books. However, the following parts, introducing about the monetary and fiscal policies, are really diverse. This book uses USA Federal Reserve as an example and discusses the measures qualitatively, while our textbooks simply says the several policies together with the supply-side ones and then use graphs and numerical method to describe.

Both qualitative and quantitative analysis methods are acceptable, but from my point of view, I prefer use quantitative one more because it provides us with the extent to which the policy may be effective and useful, while qualitative ones may only says the changes instead of giving us a possibility to compare the forecast and the reality.

entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter8 The social security system, welfare spending, & healthcare in the United States
entry.content:
Extract

PartA Social security: A ticking time bomb?

  • Some people are convinced that the US Social Security program is doomed and that the whole thing will blow apart at some point in the next few decades. Others are more optimistic about the program’s future.
  • Calling the program a time bomb is on the extreme side, but it’s true that Society Security needs some adjustments to remain solvent for future generations.
  • The Social Security program wasn’t originally intended to provide a retiree’s sole source of income, and that’s still true today. The original program looked different from today’s, as many changes have been made to it over the years.
  • In theory, the Social Security Trust Fund exists, but the fund is really more of an accounting trick than a true pension fund, and it is projected to run out by 2034. Other portions of the Social Security system, such as disability insurance, are projected to be out of money much sooner.
  • The systems basic problem, and the reason why it won’t work as well in the future as it did in the past, is demographics.
  • The myth of the Social Security Trust Fund
    • Most people already understand that the Social Security benefits paid to current recipients are funded by current workers’ payroll taxes, but there’s something else that many people don’t realise.
    • The Social Security system essentially lent the surpluses to the government, and the government used that money for many other purposes.
  • Fixing Social Security: A menu of Options
    • But there’s a menu of possible actions that could be taken to address the problem, and they all boil down to either increasing the revenues flowing into the program, or reducing the monies paid out.
      • Raise the payroll tax rate.
      • Raise or gradually eliminate the Social Security payroll cap.
      • Expand the base of workers from whom the payroll tax is collected.
      • Allow more legal immigrants into the country.
      • Reduce benefits.
      • Raise the retirement age.
      • Introduce means testing.
      • Privatise the Social Security program.
    • That’s another reason why the problem with Social Security has persisted — Social Security has been called the “third rail” of American politics because, metaphorically speaking, politicians who touch on this subject experience the same effect they would had they touched the electrified rail that runs along a subway track.
    • What you’ll probably discover is that there’s no single solution on which everyone can agree.
    • Failure to act on the issue today will only push the problem — and a drastically compounded problem at that — onto the backs of future generations.

PartB The debate over welfare spending in the United States

  • Efficiency
    • Efficiency is just what it sounds like, at least to an economist: the optimal production and allocation of resources.
    • In such a system, a high income would serve as a reward, or motivator, to get highly productive people producing even more. With highly productive people producing more, others in the economy would benefit. The economy would grow at a faster rate, more goods and services would be produced, and jobs would be created.
  • Equity
    • Equity has to do with fairness or equality, but there are different ways of understanding what equity and equality mean.
    • One form of redistribution is the progressive income tax, the system that requires high earners to pay a larger proportion of their income in taxes than low earners are required to pay. Another form of income redistribution is government sending on welfare programs for poor people.
  • Welfare’s costs and benefits
    • Some critics see the higher taxes needed to finance welfare spending as dampening the productive efforts of high earners.
    • Others argue that welfare benefits undermine the work ethic of recipients, and that economic growth suffered to the extent that welfare benefits discourage people from working.
    • Welfare spending’s greatest benefit may be its potential to lessen income inequality.
      • Many people find value in feeling that they live in a country that is becoming more socially just, and when concerns about income inequality are eased by increased welfare spending, we’re better off as a society.
      • Some analysts argue that a high degree of income inequality may reduce a country’s rate of economic growth. Reducing income inequality would therefore benefit a country’s rate of economic growth.
    • The net effect of all of these factors is unknown at this time, but currently politicians believe that the funds spent on welfare programs are justified.

PartC Healthcare: A market like no other

  • The healthcare industry is one of the nation’s most heavily regulated industries; the same is true in most nations, for that matter.
  • The vast majority of hospitals in the United States operate on a nonprofit basis, so they pursue goals aside from profit maximisation.
  • The healthcare market is characterised by asymmetric information and having an ill-defined product since the outcome of healthcare is uncertain.
  • Because of asymmetric information and an ill-defined product, not to mention the effects of injury and illness, healthcare consumers may make less rational decisions about healthcare than they do about other products.
  • Thanks to combinations of insurance premiums, co-payments, and government subsidies, consumers only rarely pay the full price for healthcare services.
  • Because the wedge between consumers and producers disguises true costs, consumers tend to overconsume healthcare services because they’re not paying the full costs.
  • By contrast, free market advocates argue that the government is already too involved in healthcare. Some who take this view also contend that government is the cause of the healthcare system’s problems.
  • Should the Healthcare Market Be Given Free Rein?
    • There would be people who couldn’t afford health insurance.
    • There would be people, especially young and very healthy people, who would choose not to buy health insurance even if they could afford it.
    • In a pure market system, insurers would have the right to accept the customers they wanted to insure and turn away the rest.
    • People who have health insurance tend to overconsume healthcare, as we’ve seen, and their overconsumption drives up costs.
  • What about a government-run, single-payer system?
    • In a national healthcare system, all citizens have access to healthcare regardless of income, age, or health status.
    • Costs can also be more tightly controlled in a single-payer system — the government has virtually all the negotiating power, and a single payer can realise certain economics of scale that are not available in a multiplayer system.
    • Another advantage of a national healthcare system is that health insurance can be uncoupled from employment.
    • Yet a number of problems would likely appear in connection with a national healthcare system.
      • The government would have to set standards for care, and some argue that ultimately the quantity and the quality of healthcare would decline.
      • People would find themselves waiting in long lines for treatment.
      • Rationing could become a reality, especially as the population ages and the demand for healthcare rises.
      • A national healthcare system could lead to more inefficiency and bureaucracy.

Personal thinking

Healthcare has always been one of the most basic and significant industries in the country because it provides citizens with treatment.

When learning about the merit and demerit goods, my Economics teacher told me that, and the textbooks wrote that, healthcare is a merit good because it still generates extra benefits, i.e. has positive externality. This chapter discusses about the ownership of the healthcare industry. Both private and public sector will have benefits and drawbacks. As a result, now in China, this industry has both sectors in order to make sure that people can choose their preference.

When reading this chapter, I have a question about the rational choices. As the treatment is somehow expensive in China, for example, it may took us more than several hundred thousand to treat the cancer which is a common illness in nowadays society, many people may give up treatment because they think even if they are incurred, they need to pay for the debt throughout their remaining life which is not worthy, while others may believe that they need to receive treatment, no matter how expensive it is. These are two kinds of people having different values. They may make different decisions although the benefits and costs to them are the same. It is never possible for the economists to analyse people case by case. They just provide a very general solution or explanation.

entry.title: IPQ - Literature review
entry.content:
Many scholars carried out a variety of surveys about the impact of COVID-19 on the aviation industry. Most of them studied the performance of the whole industry during COVID-19 instead of focusing on a simple airline company (Maneenop, 2020). Still, there are some surveys about predicting the future condition of the industry, like demand forecasting (Garrow, 2021). These findings all showed that the industry is suffering from low revenue or other problems like cash flow. Some economists paid much attention to these questions to help the whole industry recover and reduce the loss made because of COVID-19 in the whole society.

The first essay mentioned above (Maneenop, 2020) analyses the data, including shares prices, daily returns of the stock at a time, abnormal return of the stock, and fair values from airline companies worldwide. They found the underreaction to the announcement on January 13, 2020, when reporting the first case outside China. Also, they mentioned the overreaction on March 11, 2020, when WHO announced the COVID-19 as a pandemic.

The second essay mentioned above (Garrow, 2021) concludes the key themes of a program. The closure of borders has restricted the ability to exploit the benefits of alliances. However, it holds the opinion that the aviation industry has been seeing a slow and sustained recovery. To better develop the aviation industry, we need to increase the speed and flexibility in decision-making and rethink network planning. They still think COVID-19 is a catalyst for changing and shifting development priorities as fundamental changes in passenger demand and booking patterns have shifted development priorities within airline revenue management departments. Also, revenue management can contribute to demand forecasting.

Meanwhile, because the industry can be divided mainly into domestic and international services, this is another aspect of discussing the influences. In the paper (Suau-Sanchez, 2020), the authors believed that airline companies like British Airways might face huge problems as they have built a hub on sixth freedom traffic. The hub means they have the privilege of transporting international via the carrier’s home state, traffic moving between two other States. Also, they mentioned that the regional airlines might win in the short run. Focusing on a specific area like a continent and comparing two regions are widely discussed as well. There is an essay (Milena, 2021) paying attention to the European Union as they analysed the impacts of the global pandemic on the aviation industry of the EU and the development of their air transport. They also mentioned that the decrease in demand was mainly due to government regulation. The future development may be affected by the lasting time of the COVID-19 pandemic and the extent of trust of the consumer in the aviation industry, and the consumers’ economic situation.

Additionally, SARS in May 2003 was another widespread pandemic. As a result, many scholars analysed the difference and similarities between the impact of these two noticeable epidemics. An essay (Tay, 2021) can mainly be into three parts: the current situation, the comparison with SARS, and lessons learning from SARS and the future projection from two sides. They thought airline companies must prepare for both optimistic and pessimistic scenarios to unfold and prepare for future development. They also identified critical short-term and long-term measures which we can adapt to tide through this pandemic.

Many professors are looking at the problems and difficulties while they provide the industry with general suggestions. entry.title: IPQ - Methodology
entry.content:
SPACE Matrix is the primary method employed in the report. It stands for Strategic Position and ACtion Evaluation Matrix. It is a widely used method for analysing the competitive position of organisations (Radder, 1998). Clearly, using the SPACE Matrix in the report is significantly helpful.

It contains two internal dimensions: financial strength and competitive advantage, and two external dimensions with industry strength and environmental stability. Each dimension has around seven indicators. All the indicators are given a point between 0 and 6 to evaluate the level of each indicator. This provides people with a chance to get a numerical result that is more accurate than discussion-based ones. After getting the result of all the indicators, we can calculate the average, which is a benefit of using a numerical survey. Four dimensions together will show the result. The result is to work out the strategy in the industry. The classification mainly includes four kinds of strategic posture: aggressive, competitive, conservation or defensive.

The data I used during the analysis process is from several providers, including ICAO, IATA, and United Airlines. We analyse the data from their reports that helps us work out the current situation of United Airlines.

entry.title: Thinking on Economics Through Everyday Life Chapter7 Booms, bubbles, & busts
entry.content:
Extract

PartA The basics of business cycles

  • We can blame animal spirits, irrational exuberance, or the bogeyman for that matter, but booms and bubbles — and the busts that result — have been recurring features of our economy for at least as long as economic data has been recorded.
  • The terms booms, bubble, and bust are used in the financial press because they have a dramatic ring to them, but they belong to a broader discussion of business cycles, a discussion that uses terms that aren’t nearly so dramatic.
  • Economics activity tends to rise and fall over time, and these fluctuations are commonly referred to as business cycles.
  • The presence and phases of business cycles are typically indicated and measured by changes in real GDP over time.
  • A single business cycle has four basic phases
    • At the peak of a business cycle, total production in the economy is temporarily maxed out.
    • After the economy peaks, it goes into recession.
    • A business cycle bottoms out at its trough, or low point. In the trough, real GDP is at a temporary minimum, and — unless other negative influences come into play — unemployment is at a temporary maximum.
    • The expansion phase of the business cycle begins just after the trough, and it entails the economy’s climb toward a new peak.

PartB What causes business cycles?

  • Through years of observation and research, however, economists have identified two major factors that definitely influence business cycles
    • Economic shocks
      • These are unforeseen events that affect the economy and can create fluctuations in business activity.
    • Monetary policy
  • Throughout the 1990s and into the first few years of the current century — the period of “irrational exuberance” — some analysts began to wonder whether the business cycle might even be dead. Then, in late 2007, along came a financial crisis to remind everyone that business cycles are alive and well, and that no one has yet come up with a satisfactory answer to the question of what causes them.
  • Cyclical unemployment doesn’t appear in the expansionary phase of the business cycle. It only appears in the trough or during a recession.

PartC Recessions and depressions

  • As the old economics joke has it, in a recession, your neighbours lose their jobs; in a depression, you lose yours.
  • Recessions in the United States
    • Since the end of World War II, according to the NBER, there have been 11 recessions in the United States.
    • A key feature of any recession is a broad economic downturn, but a recession doesn’t affect all industries and all firms in the same way.
  • The Great Depression
    • The Great Depression truly was “great”. No economic downturn that our country has experienced since then has equaled the Depression’s severity or its economic impact in terms of unemployment, falling stock prices, bank failures, personal bankruptcies, and all-around pain and suffering.
    • In addition to our improved understanding of the economy and monetary economics, we now have a social safety net, a system of protections that mostly didn’t exist during the Great Depression.
    • Given everything we’ve learned up to this point in our history, a repeat of the Great Depression looks like a very remote possibility.

PartD From boom to bubble to bust

  • Some people use the terms expansion and boom fairly interchangeably, and there’s actually no technical distinction between an expansion and a boom.
  • Often a boom indicates that the economy is overheating, and that suppliers of goods and services are suddenly unable to keep up with demand.
  • When prices of certain assets, such as stocks or real estate, aren’t supported by the underlying fundamentals — the factors that determine the actual market value of those assets — it’s often said that a bubble, or asset bubble, has developed (synonymous terms include speculative bubble, market bubble, and price bubble).
  • An economic boom is typically followed by an economic bust. During a bust, real GDP falls, unemployment rises, and any asset bubbles that have been brewing are not set to burst.
  • In the summer of 2015, there was a drastic drop in the prices of Chinese stocks. It turned out that the Chinese government had created an asset bubble by reporting an inaccurate growth rate for the Chinese economy.

PartE The 2007-2008 financial crisis: Who’s to blame?

  • Entire books have been written about the crisis, but in summary it began with a housing bubble fuelled by low interest rates engineered by the Fed, combined with the federal government’s encouragement for almost every American to own a home, if possible.
  • Vast numbers of home loans, including a large number of subprime loans, were sold on the secondary market by the original leaders. These loans were then bundled together, and the bundles were used to create opportunities for investors.
  • Wall Street firms began to create additional investment opportunities by issuing various kinds of derivatives, or financial instruments related to the mortgage-backed securities.
  • When housing prices finally reached unsustainable levels, the bubble burst, and the house of cards collapsed. Housing prices rapidly dropped by hundreds of thousands of dollars.
  • Many lessons have been learned from the 2007-2008 financial crisis, and there are still more to be gleaned fro retroactive examination of the facts.
    • The Fed’s low interest rates laid the foundation for a housing bubble to develop, but the low interest rates in and of themselves didn’t cause the bubble.
    • The fact that some mortgage companies engaged in questionable lending practices contributed to the problem, but the mortgage companies wouldn’t have been able to make so many subprime loans if the money had not been so readily available, and if the government hadn’t implicitly endorsed such weak lending standards.
    • The esoteric financial instruments created and marketed by Wall Street firms definitely added to the problem, but there wouldn’t have been so many of those instruments if there hadn’t been so many subprime loans availed for bundling.
    • Borrowers were sometimes the targets of predatory lending, but perhaps they should have known that they were taking out bigger loans than they could afford.
  • Clearly, there’s plenty of blame to go around for the housing bubble and the financial crisis that followed. The question of who deserves the most blame is one that will probably never have a definitive answer, at least not from anyone who tries to analyse these events objectively.

Personal thinking

These days, I watched several documentaries about the financial crisis happened by the end of the first decade of the 21st century, most of which provided basic introduction of the process from the beginning to the final solution of the crisis.

From my point of view, combined with the ideas of the documentaries and this chapter, every stakeholders in that financial crisis had part of the responsibility. For example, the investment banks such as the Lehman Brothers and Goldman, were accountable for the purchase of the subprime loans. The consulting companies provided wrong levels for the high risk loans. However, at the same time, all the stakeholders born some loss, such as Lehman Brothers as mentioned before which faced bankruptcy first, and the consulting companies which were almost bankrupt.

There are still many people in this case, including the general public. They suffered more because some of them even lost all their life savings and their house and became homeless. It is always hard for us to imagine the impact of slight changes in the era will have on an individual can be how great, saying nothing of huge events like financial crisis.

Sometimes I think, if possible in the future, I would like to discover a much more precise and accurate model for all the government to use to estimate the future trends of the country economic condition. Although the author thought that sudden crisis could not be predicted, I still believe that there are some clues for us to find and use before the crisis. This can greatly contribute to the human beings well being.

From my point of view, these skills I learnt during IPQ will benefit my work not only at university but also at the present stage of learning. I like the report most. It provided me with the most rewards because it can show me all the efforts I had devoted to developing the project.

I believe that the major successes of my project have been from four aspects. Firstly, I have chosen an appropriate topic because the topic is both narrowed and worth discussing. This topic allows me to discuss all my aims and objectives clearly and detailedly instead of spending fewer words on one objective. Meanwhile, I think I have a helpful literature table. It contains a variety of information, including the title, the researcher, the sources of the researches, the main aims of the research and their results. The table contains almost all the information I need while writing the report——this saved time for me. At the same time, this table allowed me to be clear about all the resources and increased my productivity.

Although I changed it several times due to the changes I made in the report structure, the table still played an essential role. For example, it allowed me to write the report in the summer much more straightforwards. The plan increased my efficiency by a considerable extent. Also, it allowed enough time after finishing the writing for proofreading and double-checking.

There are several failures during the project. For example, during August, I was busy attending a summer school aimed at academic achievements. Summer school took most of my time. However, I still planned to finish writing some parts of my discussion to ensure I can complete everything before the deadline. At that time, I ended up having a large workload.

To sum up, while making the plan, I overestimated my spare time and my extra energy. Meanwhile, I thought I spent too much time finishing the literature table and literature review, although the table is helpful and excellent. However, I still found that I did not fully use almost half of the information during proofreading. If I had spent less time, I might start writing the discussion part earlier and proofreading and double-checking.

If I were to undertake the project again, I would improve the logic of planning. As I mentioned above, sometimes I was extremely overload. Additionally, during the process, I talked to my supervisor only several times. Sometimes the direction of my writing went wrong. If I had talked to my supervisor more frequently, I could avoid the mistakes in direction and save some time.

It is worth mentioning that I thought I had developed several vital skills during the project. The way can contribute to my study when my teachers and supervisors can not provide me with supports immediately. Lastly, this also taught me to collect and collate information and data efficiently. As I have decided to major in Economics at the university, this will help me during quantitative analysis.

An appropriate topic will provide the students with a clear pathway to develop the whole project. Also, this will significantly decrease the workload. If you choose to carry on a broad topic that includes tens of the subtopics, you need to read many essays and previous studies. entry.title: Section2 The allocation of resources
entry.content:
Market

Demand

  • Definition: Demand is the willingness and ability to buy a product

  • Law of demand: Quantity demanded and price are inversely related. When the price falls, the demand rises.(Normal Goods)

  • Differentiate

    • Quantity demanded

      • Actual quantity at a certain price

    • Demand

      • Not a quantity but all the relation between price and quantity demanded

  • Determinations

    • Price

      • Change in quantity demanded

        • Extension in demand

          • Definition: Movement along the demand curve when quantity demanded increases due to a fall in the price of the product itself.

        • Contraction in demand

          • Definition: Movement along the demand curve when quantity demanded decreases due to an increase in the price of the product itself.

    • Non-price

      • Change in demand

        • Increase

          • Definition: a rise in quantity demanded at any given price, causing the demand curve to shift to the right

        • Decrease

          • Definition: a decrease in quantity demanded at any given price, causing the demand curve to shift to the left

      • Price of related goods

        • Substitutes

          • Definition: It is a product that can be used in place of another. They can satisfy the same want
          • price of substitute increase–>demand for substitute contract–>demand for the product increase–>price of the product increase

        • Complements

          • Definition: It is a product that is used together with another product. Complements are in joint
          • price of complement increase–>demand for complement contract–>demand for the product reduce–>price of the product decrease

      • Income

        • Normal goods

          • When income increases, the demand for it increases

        • Inferior goods

          • When income decrease, the demand for it increases

      • Successful advertising

        • More heavily, more demand

      • Interest rate

        • An increase in interest rate creates incentive for consumers to save more and purchase less, so the demand decreases

      • Population

        • An increase in population, an increase in demand

      • Fashion, taste, habit

      • Other factors

        • change in weather conditions
        • expectation
        • special events

Supply

  • Definition: It is the willingness and ability of firms to produce and sell a product.

  • Law of supply: Quantity supplied and price are directly related. When the price falls, the supply rises.

  • Differentiate

    • Quantity supply

      • Actual quantity at a certain price

    • Supply

      • Not a quantity but all the relation between price and quantity supplied

  • Determinations

    • Price

      • Change in quantity supplied

        • Extension in supply

          • Definition: Movement along the supply curve when quantity supplied increases due to a rise in the price of the product itself.

        • Contraction in supply

          • Definition: Movement along the supply curve when quantity supplied decreases due to a decrease in the price of the product itself.

    • Non-price

      • Change in supply

        • Increase

          • Definition: a rise in quantity supplied at any given price, causing the supply curve to shift to the right

        • Decrease

          • Definition: a decrease in supplied demanded at any given price, causing the supply curve to shift to the left

      • Costs of production

        • An increase in the costs of production results in an decrease in supply(want a higher price for it)

      • Improvement in technology

        • raise productivity, reduce costs of production, increase supply

      • Taxes

        • Only direct taxes on firms including corporation taxes, and indirect tax including VAT and excise duty
        • an increase in tax–>more expensive to supply a product and reduce supply

      • Subsidies

        • an increase in subsidy–>cheaper to supply, decrease in costs of production and increase supply

      • Price of other products

        • firms may choose to produce more other goods produced by the firms as an increase in other goods’ price and supply(opportunity cost)

      • Other factors

        • weather conditions and health of livestock and crops
        • disasters and wars
        • discoveries and depletions of commodities

Price determination

  • Definition: Equilibrium price is the price where quantity demanded and quantity supplied are equal. There is no pressure to change the price.

  • Disquilibrium

    • Definition: It is the situation where quantity demanded and quantity supplied are not equal

    • Surplus(Excess supply)

      • Definition: It is a situation where quantity demanded is greater than quantity supplied

    • Shortage(Excess demand)

      • Definition: It is a situation where quantity supplied is than quantity demanded

Price change

  • Equilibrium price increases

    • Demand increases

      • Quantity increases

    • Supply decreases

      • Quantity decreases

  • Equilibrium price decrease

    • Demand decreases

      • Quantity decreases

    • Supply increases

      • Quantity increases

Elasticity

PED

  • Definition: It measures the extent to which the quantity demanded changes when the price of the product changes

  • Formula: PED=percentage change in quantity demanded/percentage change in price

    • Sign

      • In the vast majority of cases, it is minus.

    • Size

      • This indicates the extent by which demand will extend or contract when price changes

  • Classification

    • Elastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price results in a greater percentage change in quantity demanded
      • 1<PED<infinity
      • It is illustrated by a shallow curve
      • An increase in price results in a fall in revenue

    • Inelastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price results in a smaller percentage change in quantity demanded
      • 0<PED<1
      • It is illustrated by a steep curve
      • An increase in price results in an increase in revenue

    • Perfectly elastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes a complete change in the quantity demanded
      • PED=infinity
      • It is illustrated with a horizontal curve
      • An increase in price results in a fall in revenue

    • Perfectly inelastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes on change in the quantity demanded
      • PED=0
      • It is illustrated with a vertical curve
      • An increase in price results in an increase in revenue

    • Unit elasticity of demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes an equal change in the quantity demanded, leaving the total revenue unchanged
      • PED=1
      • An increase in price has no effect on revenue

  • Determination

    • Degree of necessity

      • Necessities tend to have a relative inelastic demand

    • Availability of close substitutes

      • Available substitutes result in an elastic demand

    • Proportion of income

      • A high proportion of income tends to result in elastic demand

    • Time period under consideration

      • In long run, consumers have more time to change habit, so it results in elastic demand

    • Addictive goods

      • Addictive goods tend to have an inelastic demand

  • Implications

    • Consumers

      • Benefit from lower prices and higher quality when demand is elastic

    • Producers

      • help them to decide on their pricing strategy
      • try to make the firm’s product more distinctive to make the demand for firm’s product more price inelastic and would give the producer more power to raise price

    • Governments

      • help them make a decision on its subsidy and taxation policies
      • discouraging consumption is more likely to be successful if demand is elastic

PES

  • Definition: It measures the extent to which the quantity supplied changes when the price of the product changes

  • Formula: PES=percentage change in quantity supplied/percentage change in price

    • Sign

      • It is a positive figure

    • Size

      • This indicates the degree of responsiveness of the quantity supplied to a change in price

  • Classification

    • Elastic supply

      • It occurs when the quantity supplied changes by a greater percentage than the change in price
      • 1<PES<infinity
      • It is illustrated by a shallow curve

    • Inelastic supply

      • It occurs when the quantity supplied changes by a smaller percentage than the change in price
      • 0<PES<1
      • It is illustrated by a steep curve

    • Perfectly elastic supply

      • It occurs when a change in price causes a complete change in quantity supplied
      • PES=infinity
      • It is illustrated by a horizontal curve

    • Perfectly inelastic supply

      • It occurs when a change in price has no effect on the quantity supplied
      • PES=0
      • It is illustrated by a vertical curve

    • Unit PES

      • It occurs when a change in price causes an equal percentage change in the quantity supplied

  • Determination

    • Time taken to produce it

      • If it takes a short time producing, the supply is more likely to be price elastic. It is more likely to be price elastic in long run.

    • Number of producers in the industry

      • More suppliers in the industry results in a more elastic supply

    • Feasibility of storing it

      • A higher level of stocks of finished goods results in the supply being more elastic

  • Implications

    • Consumers

      • benefit from supply being elastic

    • Producers

      • benefit from supply being elastic

    • Governments

      • benefit from supply being elastic

Economic system

Three fundamental questions

  • What goods and services should be produced? (Three sectors)
  • How should the goods and services be produced?
  • For whom should get the goods and services produced?

Sectors

  • Public sector

    • It is controlled by the government. It covers government run services and state-owned enterprises

  • Private sector

    • It covers business organisations which are owned by shareholders or individuals. These organisation respond to changes in market forces and are profit motivated

Planned Economic

  • Definition: It is an economic system where the government makes the crucial decisions, land and capital are state-owned and resources are allocated by government

Market Economic

  • Basic information

    • Definition: It is an economic system where consumers determine what is produced, resources are allocated by the price mechanism and land and capital are privately owned.

    • Intensive

      • Capital-intensive
      • Labour-intensive

    • Feature

      • Consumer sovereignty
      • Government intervention is minimal
      • Price mechanism

  • Advantages

    • Competitions(to consumers)

      • The nature of a market system determines the levels of competition

      • Advantages

        • Consumer sovereignty
        • Lower prices
        • High quality
        • Many choices

    • Incentives

      • To gain profits and avoid losses(firms)–>try to meet consumers’ needs and wants in order to obtain and maintain consumers
      • To receive high incomes(workers)–>develop skills, work hard, take more responsibility, be more mobile

    • Allocative efficiency（quantity)

      • Firm produce the products that consumers demand in the right quantities
      • Market forces, by changing prices, should eliminate shortages and surpluses and move market towards allocative efficiency.
      • (a competitive market)have both incentive in the form of profit and a threat of punishment in the form of a risk of going out business

    • Production efficiency(Average cost)

      • It produces at the lowest possible average cost
      • (a competitive market)have both incentive and a threat of punishment
      • Producing on PPC

    • Dynamic efficiency(Average costs continue to decrease)

      • The efficiency occurring over time as a result of investment and innovation
      • profit incentive and threat of going out of business

  • Disadvantages

    • Market failure

      • Underproduction(shortage)

      • Overproduction(surplus)

      • Definition: It occurs when market forces of demand and supply fail to produce the right products to the consumers in the right amount and at the lowest cost.(Seen as allocative inefficency)

      • Classification

        • Externality

          • It is the consumption and production of some products may affect third parties(social benefit>private benefit or social cost>private cost)
          • Definition: Social costs are the total costs to a society of an economic activity. Private costs are the costs borne by those directly consuming or producing a product. External costs are costs imposed on third parties
          • Definition: Social benefits are the total benefits to a society of an economic activity. Private benefits are the benefits received by those directly consuming or producing a product. External benefits are benefits enjoyed by the third parties
          • Formula: social=private+external

        • Information failure

          • Needed

            • Consumer

              • nature of the products and the benefits they can receive form them and their prices

            • Workers

              • the jobs, locations, qualifications required, remuneration and the nature of jobs for which their skills are best suited

            • Producers

              • consumer demand, raw material with good quality and lowest prices, most cost-efficient production methods

          • It occurs when there may be a lack of information or inaccurate information.(also called asymmetric information)

        • Merit/Demerit goods

          • Merit

            • Definition: It is the products which the government considers consumers do not fully appreciate how beneficial they are and so which will be under-consumed if left to market forces(positive externality)
            • Solution: Providing subsidy to produces; Government provision; Providing information; Financial incentive for consumers

          • Demerit

            • Definition: It is the products which the governments consider consumers do not fully appreciate how harmful they are and so which will be over-consumed if left to market forces(negative externality)
            • Solution: Increase taxes; Increase advertisement against consumption; Law to limit consumption; Limit import

        • Public goods

          • Features

            • Non-excludability
            • Non-rivalry

        • Abuse of monopoly power

          • Monopoly; Oligopoly; Monopolistic Competitive
          • No choice but to buy even at high prices
          • Solution: Remove entry barriers; Making uncompetitive practices illegal; Stop firms from merging; Give subsidies to other competition firms; Implement anti-monopoly law

        • Immobility of resouces

          • Occupational immobility
          • Geographical immobility
          • Solution: Improve education and provide training; Provide investment grants; Make it easier to but or rent housing in areas where has a high demand for labour

        • Short termism

          • Market forces may not allocate resources efficiently to enable future generations to be able to enjoy them.

    • Productive inefficiency

      • Producing inside PPC
      • losing market share and profits

    • Dynamic inefficiency

      • Do not do research and development
      • Being driven out of the market

Mixed Economic

  • Basic information

    • Definition: It is an economy in which both the private and public sectors play an important role
    • The degree of public and private sectors is determined by the government
    • Essential services are provided by public sector. Governments exist to redistribute income and wealth
    • In private sector, profit motives the firms to provide goods and services

  • Advantages

    • Eliminate externalities
    • Encourage consumption of merit goods
    • Discourage consumption of demerit goods
    • Provide public goods
    • Prevent high prices(ignore monopoly)
    • Make maximum use of resources
    • A more even distribution of income and wealth

  • Disadvantages(Government failure)

    • Overestimate the extent of private benefits; Difficult to calculate the most efficient quantity of public goods to supply
    • Take time to make decisions; Decisions influenced by political factors
    • Reduce economic efficiency by reducing incentives

  • Actions taken to solve market failure

    • Price ways

      • Maximun prices
      • Minimum prices

    • Non-price ways

      • Indirect taxation

        • Levy an indirect tax on demerit goods to decrease supply in order to reducing demand for these products

      • Subsidies

        • Provide a subsidy to increase supply to encourage the consumption of certain goods and services

      • Regulations

        • Definition: Regulations are rules which are designed to influence the behaviour of firms

      • Educations

      • Nationalisation

        • Definition: It is moving the ownership and control of an industry from the private sector to the government

        • Advantages

          • Decisions on the full costs and benefits involved
          • Be used to influence economic activity
          • Government monopoly will not abuse market power
          • Make planning and coordination easier
          • Ensure basic industries to survive, charge low prices and produce good quality

        • Disadvantages

          • Difficult to manage and control(DOS)
          • Inefficient, produce low quality products and charge relatively high prices, due to a lack of competition and the knowledge that they cannot go bankrupt
          • Need to be subsidised if making loss(OC of government revenue)

      • Privatisation

        • Definition: It is moving the ownership and control of an industry from the government to the private sector

        • Advantages

          • The ability to earn one-off privatisation proceeds from the sale of state-owned assets.
          • Reduce government debts(No longer has to maintain the operation; earns revenue from selling the business; earns taxes)
          • Reduce costs to taxpayers
          • Incentive to improve efficiency, risking taking and innovation

        • Disadvantages

          • Consumers may face higher prices
          • To protect the public interest, privatisation may still require government regulation and intervention.
          • OC（State-owned enterprises provide social benefits)

      • Direct provision

        • Definition: Governments provide certain goods and services free of charge to their citizens

        • Advantages

          • The goods and services are accessible to all people in society
          • private benefits for the individual and external benefits for third parties in society

        • Disadvantages

          • OC
          • Free goods and services may be over-consumed
          • In the case of a shortage of supply caused by excess demand, it can be difficult to decide who should be able to take advantage of the free government service.
          • Free riders take advantage of free goods and services without contributing to government revenue by paying taxes.

Economy

Economy is that people and firms produce, exchange and consume goods and services

Microeconomics is the study of the behaviour and decisions of households and firms and the performance of individual markets.

Macroeconomics is the study of the whole economy.

Decision makers

  • Also called economic agents

  • Household

    • including consumers, savers and workers
    • Consumers aim at low price and good quality products
    • Workers aim at good working conditions and high pay
    • Savers aim at their money to be safe and to give a good return

  • Firm

    • They are the business concerns that produce goods and services and employ workers and other FOPs
    • Firms(in private sector)aim at making as much profit as possible

  • Government

    • It is the system which rules a country or region. It produces and provides some products, financial benefits, and levies taxes on and regulates the private sector
    • Government aims at a strong economy and improve the performance of individual markets

The balance sheet provides information about the trend in the changes in assets and liabilities. The total assets and total current show an increasing trend. The current liabilities reached a peak in 2019, while the total liabilities keep rising until 2020. Stockholders’ equity, an essential data considered by the investors, has risen for four years. This increase is an advantage to the investors.

The current ratio, another data considered, has the formula to calculate.

We can use the data in Table. 5. to calculate the trend of current ratio.

The current ratio increased significantly. The figure for 2020 is more than twice the figure for the previous three years. As the airline companies are very special, figures around 0.5 seem to be more common. For example, the current ratio of Delta Air Lines in 2019 is 0.41. This increase may be disadvantageous because a current ratio larger than 1.0 may show that the company has too much money in their account. If the money is not used efficiently, it can not create maximum value for the company.

Information, including the trend of the stockholders’ equity, the trend of assets and liabilities, and the current ratio, shows that United Airlines is performing better and better even under the broad background of COVID-19.

In the current environment, airline companies like United Airlines need to consider cash flow because cash may strap the company, and cash flow is a prerequisite for survival.
