Net income, one of the essential indicators considered by the investors, decreased in 2020, while the net cash provided by (used in) operating activities has a similar trend. The decrease is not a good signal. All the data shows that United Airlines was in a dire cash flow condition in 2020.

Share prices, also known as stock price, is another indicator of the company’s performance.

United Airlines’ common stock is listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol “UAL”(United Airlines, 2021).

Line Chart. 1. Performance Graph

Source: UAL. “2020 Annual Report.” United Airlines, 1 Mar. 2021, https://ir.united.com/static-files/a30cf7ec-7b4a-4fd9-9ae3-2656e9d53f24.

The graph provides information about the cumulative total stockholder return for UAL’s common stock and the cumulative returns of the Standard and Poor’s 500 Index (“SPX”) and the NYSE Arca Airline Index (“XAL”) of 15 investor-owned airlines during the five years.

UAL showed an increasing trend in the first four years from $100 to more than $150, but in 2020 it dropped dramatically to approximately $70. XAL had a similar trend. However, the extent it changed is slighter than UAL. SPX is different. It kept rising from $100 to $190 by the end.

United Airlines had almost the average performance in the aviation industry. Additionally, we can find that the overall aviation industry, also United Airlines, performed worse than the whole economy.

In conclusion, United Airlines did not perform well in 2020 from many aspects, including the cash flow, income and stock prices, mainly due to COVID-19. Luckily, the whole industry and economy are recovering slowly (ICAO, 2021).

II. Provide suggestions on future development

The following part will use SPACE Matrix Analysis which stands for Strategic Position and ACtion Evaluation Matrix. We use SPACE Matrix Analysis to work out the strategy of United Airlines in the future. It contains four dimensions, including financial strength, competitive advantage, industry strength and environmental stability. The former two are the internal ones, while the latter two are the external ones. Each dimension has around seven indicators. In the following part, we will discuss each dimension. At the beginning of each dimension, we will show all the dimensions’ indicators and then discuss them respectively. All the indicators will be given a point from 0 to 6 to evaluate the level of each indicator. After discussing all the indicators of one dimension, we will calculate the average point of all the indicators. Four dimensions together will show the result.

We will firstly talk about Environmental stability. It has many indicators, including technological changes, inflation rate, demand variability, the price range of competing products, barriers to entry into the market, competitive pressure, and the price elasticity of demand (Radder, 1998).

Technological change is a shift to a new production function resulting from an increase in the efficiency of a product or process. The shift is the primary source of potential economic growth, which an outward shift of the Productive Possibility Curve of a company, an industry, or the whole economy can represent. United Airlines highly depends on technology. It is reported that in 2021 the Company booked 25 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft (United Airlines, 2021). Also, many media said that the Company had an upcoming IT investment (Malone, 2021). I will give point 1 to technological changes.

Competitive pressure affects a company’s incentives to undertake product and process innovations (Boone, 2000). The aviation industry is a highly competitive market, although we mentioned above that it is an oligopoly. So I will give point 1 to competitive pressure.

The price range of competing products is another indicator. Competing products can be understood as substitutes. There are lots of substitutes for the products of United Airlines. For example, the airline services provided by Delta Air Lines and American Airlines. There are still many other ways of transportation like coaches and trains. So I will give point 1 to the price range of competing.

Demand variability is a measure of how much variability there is in customer demand. We assume that the demand variability is relatively large because of the availability of substitutes and the low degree of necessities. I will give point 2 to demand variability.

Price elasticity of demand (PED) measures the responsiveness of the quantity demanded for a product when the price changes. The formula is: . We can not obtain accurate data about PED, but we can estimate it. We assume that during COVID-19, the demand for airline services did not change while their supply decreased due to travel restrictions. Quantity demanded for them decreased as well. At the same time, the revenue dropped. So the demand for them may be price elastic. There are several other indicators. For example, close substitutes are available, including the train and ship. However, it is likely to take up a high proportion of people’s incomes. So I will give point 2 to price elasticity of demand.

The rate of inflation, which is an increase in general price level and a decrease in purchasing power, has many indicators, including Consumer Price Index and Wholesale Price Index. The inflation rate was 1.81% in 2019, 1.25% in 2020, and was predicted to be 2.26% in 2021 (Statista, 2021). These rates are not high inflation rates, as FED set the inflation target at 2% (FED, 2021). I will give point 3 to the rate of inflation.

When discussing the aviation industry, the barriers to entry into the market are relatively high because this industry is capital-intensive. It requires the investors to buy huge capital goods, including aircraft, which need a considerable amount of money. It is defined as an oligopoly by FED because mergers between 2005 and 2015 decreased the number of airline companies significantly. After that, four airlines controlled 80 per cent of the US market in 2015 (Mutzabaugh, 2015). Additionally, the competition for airport gates and significant economies of scale increase the barriers (FED, 2018). So I will give point 5 to barriers to entry.

In conclusion, the average point for environmental stability is approximately 2.14.

Then, we will discuss industry strength. It includes many indicators like growth potential, profit potential, financial stability, technological know-how, resource utilisation, capital intensity, ease of entry into the market, productivity or capacity utilisation, and flexibility or adaptability (Radder, 1998).

Capital intensity is one of the indicators of barriers to entry mentioned above. The aviation industry is capital intensive because of the high demand for aircraft to transport people and products. As this industry is capital intensive, I will give it point 1 for capital intensity.

A stable financial system can provide vital services to households and businesses in good times and bad (Bank of England, 2019). Because of COVID-19, it is hard for United Airlines to control its revenue, expenditure and cash flow. Also, the cash flow performed poorly in 2020. So I will give it point 1.

Productivity utilisation is the extent to which a firm or nation employee its installed productive capacity. As we can find from the annual report (United Airlines, 2021), the number of passengers and available seat miles, the number of seats available for passengers multiplied by the number of scheduled miles those seats flown, can be used.

2020 2019 2018 2017 2016
Passengers (thousands) 57,761 162,443 158,330 148,067 143,177
Available seat miles (millions) 122,804 284,999 275,262 262,386 253,590

Table. 5. Capacity

Source: UAL. “2020 Annual Report.” United Airlines, 1 Mar. 2021, https://ir.united.com/static-files/a30cf7ec-7b4a-4fd9-9ae3-2656e9d53f24.

The number of passengers increased before 2019. However, in 2020, it declined dramatically, remaining only one-third compared with 2019. The available seat miles has the same trend. In 2020, it fell from 284,999 million to only 122,804 million. Also, the annual report mentioned that the Company cut, relative to 2019 capacity, approximately 57% of its scheduled capacity for 2020 (United Airlines, 2021). So I will give point 1 for productivity utilisation.

The profit potential is the potential for a product to generate revenue which, after expenses, leads to net income. As we are considering the profitability of United Airlines in the near future, the travel restrictions may not be loosened in the short run due to the continuous COVID-19 pandemic. It may keep negative profitability in 2021, similar to 2020, which is mentioned above. So I will give it point 2.

Technological know-how is the set of knowledge and skills that participants have developed and used to guide the acquisition, creation and operation of computer-based systems that enable or facilitate the performance of business processes (Hartono, 2011). As the aviation industry has exactly simple technology, I will give it point 2.

The flexibility of United Airlines is hard to get. However, the civil aviation industry is a member of the tertiary sector, which means it mainly provides customers with services instead of goods. Services can be customised. Meanwhile, the unique point of the aviation industry is that although it is in the tertiary sector, it is still a capital-intensive industry. Sometimes it is hard for them to respond to customers’ wants. For example, the company can not create a new airline in the short term. So I will give point 3 for it.

Growth potential is the future ability of an organisation to gain higher profits, expand the workforce and increase output (Lebeaux, 2012). United Airlines booked up to 25 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft in 2021 (United Airlines, 2021). It is highly possible to grow in the future because of the higher productive potential caused by more capital goods. I will give it point 4.

Resource utilisation means the extent of the use of the resources, which is hard to measure. However, we estimate that as United Airlines is capital intensive, it is highly possible to use its capital resources thoroughly. It is relatively efficient. So I will give it point 5.

It is not easy for investors to enter into aviation market. As mentioned above, it has high start-up costs to purchase capital goods, including aircraft, which increase the barriers to enter the market significantly. So I will give it point 5 for the ease of entry into the market.

In conclusion, the overall mark for industry strength is approximately 2.667.

Then I will talk about Competitive advantage. It includes indicators like market share, product quality, product life cycle, product replacement cycle, customer loyalty, competition’s capacity, technological know-how and vertical integration (Radder, 1998).

As United Airlines is in the tertiary sector, vertical integration means it merges with the providers of the raw materials. However, it seems that United Airlines is fond of horizontal integration. So I will give it point 2.

Technological know-how is mentioned above. The point is 2.

The product replacement cycle is the time between the purchase of an asset and its replacement with an equivalent asset.

Items Estimated Useful life (in years)
Aircraft, space engines and related notable parts 25 ~ 30
Aircraft seats 10 ~ 15
Buildings 25 ~ 45
Other property and equipment 3 ~ 15
Computer software 5 ~ 15
Building improvements 1 ~ 40

Table. 6. Product replacement cycle

Source: UAL. “2020 Annual Report.” United Airlines, 1 Mar. 2021, https://ir.united.com/static-files/a30cf7ec-7b4a-4fd9-9ae3-2656e9d53f24.

Most of the assets have a relative long product replacement cycle. I will give point 3.

In 2020, Southwest had the largest market share at 19.78% in the domestic market, while Delta Air Lines had the second-largest market share at 14.37%. America Airlines and United Airlines followed the previous two at 16.83% and 8.92%, respectively. It is the fourth-largest airline company in the US. I will give it point 4 in market share.

It seems that product quality is hard to measure because it is the personal feeling about the services provided by United Airlines. However, there is still statistic on the consumers’ feelings of the product quality of United Airlines. It is approximately 3.3 out of 5 points (Comparably, 2021), while American Airlines has 3.6 and British Airways has 3.6. I will give point 4 on the product quality.

Competition’s capacity is more about the degree of competition in the industry. As the number of airline companies is relatively low in both the USA and the world market, we consider the aviation industry as an oligopoly market. I will give point 4 because the level of competition is relatively high.

The product life cycle is relatively long. Also, it has not been changed for years and is predicted to remain in the future because of a lack of substitutes and a high degree of necessity. So the point is 4.

It is noticeable that United Airlines has a unique program called MileagePlus designed to accumulate the miles consumers travel to increase customer loyalty (United Airlines, 2021). This program produced $1.8 billion in earnings last year before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation. It also said that the program had more than 100 million members. I will give point 6 to customer loyalty.

The overall grade for competitive advantage is 3.375.

Finally, we will look at the financial strength. It contains many indicators, including the return on investment, leverage, liquidity, capital required, cash flow, ease of exit from the market and risk involved in the business.

Capital available is another important indicator. As United Airlines operates in the aviation industry, it is capital intensive. So the point for it is 1.

When looking at ease of exit from the market, the critical point is the barriers to exit. It may be hard for United Airlines to leave the market because it owns many capital goods, including aircraft. Also, it has much debt owed to investors, so United Airlines may not be able to find a buyer to buy all the aircraft and repay the debts. Meanwhile, the depreciation of the aircraft may make it challenging to repay the debts even they find a buyer. I will give point 1 on ease of exit from the market.

As we mentioned above, when looking at the cash flow statement of United Airlines, we found that it performed very bad in 2020. The free cash flow was negative. This trend may continue in the future years because of COVID-19 and low net income. I will give it point 1.

The leverage is in bad condition.

Jun 2021 Mar 2021 Sep 2020 Jun 2020 Mar 2020
Leverage ration MRQ 13.49 10.84 7.74 5.45 4.63

Table. 7. Leverage

Source: —. “United Airlines Holdings Inc Leverage Ratio (UAL) Starting from Second Quarter 2021 to Second Quarter 2020, Financial Strength Trends, Rankings, Comparisons, Financial Ratios - CSIMarket.” CSIMarket, 2021, https://csimarket.com/stocks/singleFinancialStrength.php?code=UAL&Le.

We can see that the leverage ratio is keeping rising since March 2020. It is imbalanced. So I will give it point 2.

The annual report of United Airlines by the end of 2020 mentioned the risks involved in the business. There are some risks that COVID-19 caused. These risks did not appear before the outbreak. As human beings still suffer from COVID-19, these risks may last long until scientists develop an effective vaccine and most people get vaccinated. Also, we can not avoid risks such as reliance on technology and third-party providers (United Airlines, 2021) because the business is still running. Compared with the risks that appeared before COVID-19, I will give point 2 to risk involved in business to represent the increasing risks.

Liquidity can be concluded from the cash flow table, especially the free cash flow. It shows that United Airlines has imbalanced liquidity, so I will give it point 2.

We use return on investment to evaluate how well an investment has performed

(Investopedia, 2021). It is a percentage, and we calculate it by dividing an investment’s net profit by its initial costs or outlay.

Line Chart. 2. ROI

We can see from the Charts that the ROI decreased from the end of 2019 to December 2020. Luckily, it shows an increasing trend after that. So I will give it point 3.

The overall grade for financial strength is approximately 1.857.

Using the SPACE matrix, we find that United Airlines may take defensive actions. It needs to keep its costs low and decrease the investment. Although based on the theory, it should leave the industry. However, as the whole economy suffers from the recession caused by the pandemic of COVID-19, we still suggest they remain in the industry, waiting for recovery.

Compare, to what extent, the advantages and disadvantages of rubbish landfill and incineration

Group: Salt fish

Members: Sylvia Dai; Yuki Yang; Tiffany Li; Vivian Yan.

Date: Thursday, June 24, 2021

Acknowledgement

We would like to express our special thanks of gratitude to our teachers Mr. Abass, Ms. Brenda, Ms. Cindy, Ms. Dora and Mr. Paul who provided us with help during the process of completing the project Walk Without Wall, as well as our school Nanjing Foreign Language School International Centre who gave us the this opportunity to do this wonderful project.

Brief Introduction

Our group choose to compare, to what extent, the advantages and disadvantages of rubbish landfill and incineration in Nanjing using data provided and under ideal condition. The treatment of rubbish is an important issue in the city governance. In Nanjing, landfill and incineration are the main two ways of treating the wastes, with no less than two waste incineration plants and three landfills. We will pay our attention to the Jiangnan Waste Incineration Plants run by China Everbright Environment Group Limited Nanjing Branch Office.

In order to compare the advantages and disadvantages from an economic point of view, we will calculate their costs and benefits respectively and discuss their influence on the environment in a non-database way.

Discussion about Landfill

Landfill is the oldest and most common form of rubbish disposal. Although the systematic burial of the waste with daily, intermediate and final covers began in the 1940s, it is still the most popular one. For example, in 2018, 50% of the municipal solid wastes in the U.S.A. were landfilled and 38.5% of wastes were landfilled in the EU.

In Nanjing, more than 8000ton of rubbish is produced everyday. Based on the common sense, landfilling one ton of rubbish needs one cubic meter of the land, so the land required everyday is

8000ton × 1m3/ton = 8000m3

*Before being landfilled, the rubbish needs to be treated before. Unfortunately, we do not get information about its price.

Also, the landfilled rubbish also has other negative influences, including releasing the gases and leachate and the problem of vectors and other nuisances.

  • Releasing gases

    • Landfill gas is a mix of different gases created by the action of microorganisms within a landfill as they decompose organic waste, including for example, food waste and paper waste. Landfill gas is approximately forty to sixty percent methane, with the remainder being mostly carbon dioxide. As they are green house gases, this may increase the temperature of the Earth.
    • No data available about the total quantity of gas released by one tonne of rubbish.

  • Releasing leachate

    • A leachate is any liquid that, in the course of passing through matter, extracts soluble or suspended solids, or any other component of the material through which it has passed. In the narrow environmental context leachate is therefore any liquid material that drains from land or stockpiled material and contains significantly elevated concentrations of undesirable material derived from the material that it has passed through.
    • No data available about the quantity of leachate released by one tonne of rubbish.
    • It is usually treated with special purifying system in order to reuse them in the industrial production to save water

  • Problem of vectors

    • Poorly run landfills may become nuisances because of vectors such as rats and flies which can spread infectious diseases. The occurrence of such vectors can be mitigated through the use of daily cover.
    • No data available about the quantity of vectors caused by one tonne of rubbish.

  • Other nuisances

    • Other potential issues include wildlife disruption due to occupation of habitat and animal health disruption caused by consuming waste from landfills, dust, odor, noise pollution, and reduced local property values.

The analysis above discuss the negative sides of the rubbish landfill, which can be recognised as the external costs and costs of landfill. However, as some of the external costs are hard to measure in terms of the money. As a result, we will not do further calculation.

In the following part, the benefits of the landfill will be discussed.

  • Excellent energy resource

    • As we mentioned above, landfill will release gas including carbon dioxide and methane. In the ideal condition, these gases can be collected, filtered out, and used for energy production.
    • No data available about the total quantity of gas released by one tonne of rubbish.

  • Eco-friendly

    • If the city chooses to use the modern landfills, it is eco-friendly. Older landfills were just open-air dump for nearly everything but it isn’t the case anymore. Technology is well utilized in the landfills’ design; good soil lining and leachate management system ensures no seepage and damage.

  • Keep cities, towns and districts clean

    • Any city that doesn’t have a landfill, they would simply dump waste in the vacant spots. This is unhealthy for humans and the environment. With properly maintained landfill facilities, local trash will be dealt with locally instead of shifting them to other countries.

  • Keep hazardous waste segregated

    • Landfills provide a place to dump recyclable and non-recyclable waste separately. Also, they provide a place to keep more hazardous materials that need to be segregated from the public.

  • Cheap

    • The costs only includes the costs of transportation, pre-disposal, labour and lands.

Discussion about incineration

Incineration is a waste treatment process that involves the combustion of organic substances contained in waste materials. Industrial plants for waste incineration are commonly referred to as waste-to-energy facilities. The energy is usually transferred from chemical energy into electrical energy through a.c. generator.

The plant we discuss is the Jiangnan Waste Incineration Plants run by China Everbright Environment Group Limited Nanjing Branch Office.

Fixed costs are associated with the capital investment in the first year of the proposed incinerator, including three categories of costs: land acquisition costs, equipment and technology acquisition costs and construction and installation costs. We found the percentage of the three categories of costs of Guanghan, Tianjin, China. The table below shows its total costs and percentage. As it is the similar kind of incinerator, the percentage may be similar as well.

Year Category Fixed costs(€)
2011 Incinerator land acquisition 1,230,000
2011 Incinerator equipment and technology acquisition 71,700,000
2011 Incinerator construction and installation costs 30,100,000

The total investment on the plants is 205million yuan, which is its total fixed costs. Using the figure provided.

The incinerator land acquisition is

205million × 1% = 20.5million

The incinerator equipment and technology acquisition is

205million × 70% = 143.5million

The incinerator construction and installation costs is

205million × 29% = 59.45million

The variable costs are the costs increase while the output increases. In this case, it mainly includes the collection costs from source to landfill, incinerator maintenance costs and incinerator operational costs. We found the way of calculation for the three costs respectively from an essay written by a Chinese student called Jiao Tang who was having his or her master degree in Vienna in 2012. We will show them.

  • Collection costs from source to landfill

We assume that the metals are not separated from the rest waste and also because the incinerator is within 1km distance to the current landfill. Additionally, based on the assumption that the distance between the incinerator and the landfill is 1km, the costs of collecting and transporting the residual bottom ash from the incinerator to the landfill is accounted for. The increased collection costs from source to landfill every year is therefore calculated as

Cc = (QwfII ‐ QwfI) × Pc1 + Qwl × Dl × Pc2

Where Cc is the total increased collection costs from source to landfill, QwfII the quantity of waste flow from source to the incineration plant in Scenario II, QwfI the quantity of waste flow from source to the landfill inScenario I, Pc1 the unit costs of collection per ton of waste from source to the incineration plant, Qwl the quantity of residual bottom ash that is sent to the landfill, Dl the distance between the incinerator and the landfill and Pc2 the unit costs of collection per ton per km of bottom ash from the incinerator to the landfill.

The unit cost per ton of waste from source to the incineration plant is obtained from a study done for the city of Shenzhen on municipal solid waste collection cost (Li and Kong, 2011), while the unit cost per ton of waste per km is obtained from a study done for the municipality of Heping in the city of Tianjin (Research Office of Tianjing City Heping Municipal People’s Government, 2007). Furthermore, the price of collection cost increases every year by 6.17% per annum, calculated as:

Rcr = rdn × pd/c + rwn × pw/c

where Rcr is the rate of collection costs increase per year, rdn the rate of diesel price increase per year, pd/c the percentage of diesel costs as a component of collection costs, rwn the rate of wage increase per year, and pw/c the percentage of wage costs as a component of collection costs.

  • Incinerator maintenance cocsts

Incinerator maintenance costs are the costs of maintaining and repairing the equipment at the incineration plant. According to a study on waste incineration enterprise information system (Anon, 2011), the annual costs of maintenance is approximately 3% of capital investment on the equipment.

3% × 205million = 6.15million

  • Incinerator operational costs

The yearly operational costs of the incineration plant includes utility cost (water, electricity, gas), human resource costs, costs of chemical materials needed for air pollution control, costs of auxiliary fuel when needed, costs of materials for amenity and office maintenance, the other administrative costs, excluding equipment maintenance costs. The operational costs every year are calculated as:

Co = Qwi × Po

Where Co is the operational costs, Qwi the waste input into the incinerator, and Po the unit costs of operation.

As it is impossible for us to calculate the latter two costs clearly, so the total costs can not be calculated. However, the calculation above may not be accurate out of the consideration of outmoded, floating exchange rate and inflation over the 10-year period.

Also, the incineration will have some other environmental costs.

  • Pollution

    • Incinerators produce smoke during the burning process. The smoke produced includes acid gases, carcinogen dioxin, particulates, heavy metals, and nitrogen oxide. These gases are poisonous to the environment. Research has shown that dioxin produced in the plant is a cancer forming chemical.
    • The quantity of gases produced by the plant can be got online. We can see from the table below. Every furnace produces all kinds of the gases. Although it is far less than the standard, this will still influence the environment.
Standard Furnace1 Furnace2 Furnace3 Furnace4 Furnace5 Furnace6 Furnace7
Particulate matter 20 2.38 2.79 3.73 3.68 3.52 3.11 5.14
Oxide of nitrogen 250 56.82 56.01 37.31 58.08 54.25 54.29 56.06
Sulfate dioxide (SO2) 80 1.24 1.1 2.11 2.27 4.1 6.26 14.7
Hydrogen chloride (HCl) 50 3.17 1.84 3.11 2.86 3.92 5.7 4.38
Carbon monoxide (CO) 80 4.89 2.52 6.33 5.21 2.84 1.54 3.1

  • All the data has the unit as mg/m3 and it is the average number of Saturday, June 19, 2021.

  • Damage public health

    • According to (CAP, 2013) research, the communities where incinerators plants are built, its long term effects come in the form of health hazards such as cancer, birth defects, reproductive dysfunction, neurological problems and other health effects that are known to occur at very low exposures to many of the metals, and pollutants released by incineration facilities.

  • Possibility of long-term problems

    • Incineration may create incentive for wastes and disincentive for recycling.

  • Ash wastes potentially harm people and the environment

    • Even though the ash wastes are in small quantity and dealt with before hand, it may still contain several poisons and heavy metals which require further treatment. If not disposed of correctly, it can cause serious harm to the public and the environment.

The analysis above discuss the negative sides of the rubbish incineration, which can be recognised as the external costs and costs of incineration. However, as some of the external costs are hard to measure in terms of the money. As a result, we will not do further calculation.

Fortunately, the incineration has some output which can make contribution to the economic growth. The output main includes the fly ash, the smoke, the slag and the leachate. There, at the same time, are the production of electricity using the chemical energy released from combustion.

It is possible to calculate the electricity produced in terms of the quantity and the money.

  • In quantity

    • When producing at full capacity, the total quantity of unrecyclable wastes can be dealt in one day in the two phases is

2000ton + 2000ton = 4000ton

    • It is know that one tonne of unrecyclable wastes can produce no less than 476.83 kWh of electricity. So the total quantity of electricity produced everyday is

4000t × 476.83kWh/t = 1907320 kWh ≈ 1.91 × 106 kWh

  • In money

    • It is know that price of the electricity in average is 0.35yuan/kWh*. As a result, the total revenue the plant can gain from electricity everyday is

1.91 × 106 kWh × 0.35yuan/kWh = 667562 yuan ≈ 6.7 × 105 yuan

It is also possible to calculate the water produced in terms of the money.

  • In money

    • It is know that the plant creates 2000m3/day of the leachate, most of which is turned into industrial used water. The useful water may be approximately 1800m3/day. The price of the industrial used water is 4.10yuan/m3 in China. As a result, the total revenue the plant can gain from water everyday is

1800m3/day × 4.10yuan/m3 = 7380 yuan

Meanwhile, it is said that the slag can be used to produce the bricks which are used for establishing the roads and other infrastructure. Unluckily, we do not have the data about the quantity of the slag is produced everyday.

Still, the incineration has some other benefits as well as those of landfills.

  • Decrease quantity of wastes

    • Incinerators can decrease the quantity of waste by 95% and reduce the solid quantity of the original waste by 80-85% depending on the components that were in solid waste. Hence, even though incinerators do not completely get rid of dumping ground, they definitely decrease the quantity of land needed.

  • Efficient waste management

    • Incineration plays a vital role in making waste management easier and more efficient.

  • Reduction of pollution

    • Research has shown that solid waste incinerators are less likely to pollute the environment than landfills. One particular study done during a 1994 lawsuit in the US showed that a waste incinerator location was more environment-friendly compared to a landfill. It will reduce both air pollution and water pollution.

  • Filters for trapping pollutants

    • The main problem concerning the incineration of solid waste was the release of hazardous compounds, particularly dioxin. Nonetheless, up to date incinerator plants use filters to trap hazardous gases and particulate dioxin.

  • Better control over odor and noise

  • Prevents the production of methane

  • Eliminate the harmful germs and chemicals

  • Not being influenced by the weather

  • Available computerised monitoring system

  • Occupy relative small area

Compare two methods

The information provided and data calculated above can show that the costs and benefits of the rubbish landfill and rubbish incineration respectively in perspectives of economic and environment. We will show all of them in a table to compare.

Landfill Incineration
Costs Land costs High Low
Transportation costs Same Same
Labour costs High Low
Capital costs Low High
Environmental costs High Low
Benefits Output income None High
Environmental benefits Low High

It is obvious that the landfill has much more costs than incineration and much fewer benefits. However, nowadays, many cities and countries still choose to use landfill instead of using incineration due to a lack of technology and spare money. Choosing incineration may become a future trend in the field of rubbish treatment. Still, the other new methods such as biodegrading will be developed in the near future which can make the treatment be more efficient, economical and eco-friendly.

In an essay written by a professor from South Korea mentions that among four kinds of treatment methods, including incineration, RPF boiler, RPF furnace and cement furnace, the incineration has the lowest total costs. The government and company may consider in this way during choosing the way of disposal of rubbish.

    • Effect of littering

      • Definition: Littering is the improper disposal of waste products. Littering can happen intentionally or unintentionally, but both have environmental consequences.

      • Negative consequences

        • Pollution

          • Water&Soil: chemicals and micro-particles are release which make their way into the soil and freshwater sources, impacting both humans and animals
          • Air: more than 40% of the world’s litter is burned in the open air, which can release toxic emission, causing respiratory issues (impacting humans and animals), other health problems and being a starting base for acid rain

        • Kill wildlife

          • Over one million animals die each year after ingesting or becoming entrapped in improperly discarded trash
          • Plastic litter is the most common killer and marine animals are the most notably affected. Each year over 100,000 dolphins, fish, whales, turtles and more drown after becoming entangled in or digesting plastic litter

        • Facilitates the spread of disease

          • Improperly discarded trash is a breeding ground for bacteria and diseases. Litter can spread diseases, viruses and parasites through direct and indirect contact

            • Direct contact: By picking up, touching or by accidentally injuring themselves on improperly disposed of trash
            • Indirect contact: Bacteria and parasites can be transmitted through affected vectors which are animals or insects that come in contact with contaminated litter and then transmit those contaminates to humans
