Money and Banking

Money

  • Money is an item which is generally acceptable as a means of payment.

  • Types

    • Coins
    • Notes
    • Bank accounts

  • Function

    • Medium of exchange

      • Money can be used to trade products and services. It is generally acceptable in buying and selling.

    • A store of value

      • Money can be saved and used in the future.

    • Unit of account

      • Money can be used to compare the value of different products.

    • Standard of deferred payments

      • Money allows people to borrow and lend

  • Characteristics

    • Generally acceptable(Most important)
    • Durable
    • Portable
    • Divisible
    • Homogeneous
    • Recognizable

Banking

  • Banking is a major industry in a number of countries which helps people to borrow and lend and carry out a range of other financial activities

  • Bank

    • It is a financial institution involved in money transactions.

    • Commercial bank

      • It is private sector banks which aim to make a profit by providing a range of banking services.

      • Characteristics

        • Commercial

          • Indicates that they are business organizations which seeks to make a profit

        • Joint stock

          • Limited liability and are in private sector

        • Retail

          • Sell the public something(bank services)

        • High street

          • In most of the towns and cities

      • Functions

        • Accepting money of consumers for saving (Borrowing）
        • Giving loans (Lending) as financial intermediaries
        • To make and receive payments (transmission services)
        • Selling insurance
        • Provide ‘safe deposit box’ for small valuable and documents
        • Provide exchange of currencies
        • Provide advice for financial matters
        • Provide cheque services
        • Provide credit and debit cards and Internet banking

      • Aims

        • Make a profit for its shareholders

          • By giving loans

        • Liquidity(Ensure that they can meet consumers’ requests to withdraw money from their accounts

          • By keeping a certain amount of liquid asset

    • Central bank

      • It is a government owned bank which provides banking services to the government and commercial banks

      • Functions

        • Act as a banker to the government
        • Operate as a banker to the commercial banks
        • Act as a lender of last resort
        • Manage the national debt
        • Hold the country’s reserves of golds and foreign currency
        • Issue bank notes(money)
        • Implement the government’s monetary policy
        • Supervise the banking system
        • Represent the government to meeting with other central banks and international organizationts

Households

Consumers

  • Spending

    • Factors affecting

      • Disposable income

        • In general

          • As disposable income rises, people usually spend more in total, but less as a percentage of their income

        • Poor people

          • All of their disposable income will be spent on necessities. Some may spend more than their income
          • Dissaving–>spend more than their income, either drawing on their past saving or borrowing

        • Rich people

          • Both spend and save more. The total amount spent rises with income increases, the proportion spent tends to fall

        • APC(average propensity to consume)

          • Formula: APC=consumption/disposable income
          • It shows the relationship between disposable income and consumption
          • APC decreases as disposable income increases

      • Wealth

        • Wealth generates income(dividends from shares and this income can be spent)
        • Wealth can be cashed in by withdrawing money from bank account or selling something and then spent
        • Use their wealth as security for loans
        • Wealth affects confidence(an increase in people’s house make people feel richer and spend more

      • Confidence

        • More confidence in their future career prospects and income, they may spend more

      • Interest rate

        • Savers

          • Gain more income from higher interest rate and may spend more

        • Borrowers

          • Increase costs of borrowing–>encourage saving and reduce the amount spent by people who have borrowed in the past

    • Pattern

      • Different between income groups

        • Poor

          • Spend a higher proportion of their income and total expenditure on necessities(food, clothing)

        • Rich

          • Spend more in total on food and clothes as having high quality
          • A smaller proportion of their income and total expenditure

      • Different between countries

        • Poor countries

          • Spending on necessities has a higher proportion of disposable income and total expenditure

        • Rich countries

          • Spending on luxuries forms a greater share of disposable income and total expenditure

      • Different within income groups in a country

        • Household composition

          • Households without children are likely to spend a higher proportion on entertainment than households with children

        • Tastes

        • Age

          • The retired

            • Spend a higher proportion than average on heating and a lower proportion on transport and entertainment

          • The teens

            • Spend a higher proportion on clothing and entertainment

  • Saving

    • Savings delays consumer spending to a later date

    • Dissaving is withdrawing savings to spend

    • Reasons

      • Target savers(to buy a car or a home)
      • For retirement
      • For their children’s future including education and leaving inheritance
      • To cope with emergencies and unexpected problems and take advantages of any unforeseen opportunities
      • To increase current income

    • Factors effecting

      • Disposable income

        • As disposable income rises, the total amount saved and the proportion saved increase

        • APS(average propensity to save)

          • Formula: APS=savings/disposable income
          • It shows the relationship between disposable income and savings
          • APS increases as disposable income increases

      • Wealth

        • The wealthier people are, the easier they will find it to save

      • Rate of interest

        • A rise in the rate of interest will result in an increase in saving as the reward of saving increases and create incentive for people to save

      • Tax treatment of savings

        • Tax concessions on the income eared from saving will create incentive for people to save

      • Range and quality of financial institutions

        • The greater the variety of saving opportunities on offer, the more likely people will find a scheme that will suit them
        • The more confidence in the ability of institutions to pay an interest and repay the amount saved

      • Age structure

        • The young and the old tend to save less than middle-aged people

      • Consumer and business confidence

        • More confidence in the economy, the level of savings will usually falls

      • Social attitudes

        • The attitudes to saving varies between countries.

  • Borrowing

    • It occurs when an individual, firm or the government takes out a loan from a bank or financial institution, paying it back over a period of time with interest

    • Personal debt is a total stock of money borrowed and yet to be repaid by a person or a household

    • Factors affecting

      • Availability of loans and overdrafts

        • The more bunds(controlled by the central bank) are available for lending, the more money being available for borrowing.

      • Rate of interest

        • An increase in interest rate results in a higher cost of borrowing which may reduce borrowing

      • Confidence

        • The more confident people are about the future, the more they will borrow

      • Social attitudes

        • Some countries and groups within countries are more concerned about the risk of people getting into debt by borrowing

      • Wealth

        • The wealth of a person may affect their level of borrowing as a bank will be more willing to lend money to wealthier individuals or highly profitable firms

  • Relationship between savings and borrowing

    • As disposable income rises, both the total amount saved and the proportion of disposable income saved increased.

Workers

  • Reasons for working

    • Wage factors

      • Earning is the total pay received by a worker, including basic wages, overtime pay, bonuses and commission

      • Wages

        • Piece-rate wage

          • It is a fixed amount paid per item produced or sold–variable costs of firms

        • Time-rate wage

          • It is a fixed amount paid per time span they work–variable costs of firms

      • Salaries

        • It is paid monthly at a fixed rate irrespective of the amount of work done–fixed costs of firms

      • Commission

        • It is often paid to the sales people. It is a percentage of the value of products or service sold–variable costs of firms

      • Bonus

        • It is an extra payment which is usually dependent upon performance–variable costs of firms

      • Overtime pay

        • It is an additional payment to the workers who work in excess of the standard working hours—variable costs of firms

    • Non-wage factors

      • Job satisfaction

        • Some jobs can provide a high degree of job satisfaction. eg. teachers, nurses

      • Type of work

        • Most people would rather do non-manual than manual work(Less tiring and more mental stimulation; a high status and better paid)
        • Prefer to work in a safe environment

      • Working conditions

        • People like to work in pleasant surroundings, with friendly colleagues and enjoying regular breaks

      • Pensions

        • Considerable variation in the provision of occupational pension
        • Workers in the public sector receive more generous pensions than those in private sector

      • Fringe benefits

        • It is the extra benefit provided to workers by their employers

      • Job security

        • A high degree of job security means that workers are unlikely to be made redundant
        • Civil servants often have a high degree of job security, but casual workers have little job security and can be dismissed at short notice

      • Career prospects

        • People are prepared to accept low wages at the start of their careers, if they think there is a good possibility that they will gain promotion to a well-paid and interesting post

      • Size of firms

        • People are often attracted to jobs in large firms and organisations as they provide more wages and better career prospects, job security and fringe benefits

      • Location

        • People may choose an occupation which is close to their home to save money and time

      • Working hours

        • Occupations vary in terms of the number of hours expected from workers and the timing of those hours.(Managers and senior officials tend to work for longer hours than shop workers)
        • Some occupations provide workers with opportunity to work part-time
        • Some occupations work unsociable hours including work at nights and in the evenings (night shifts and three eight-hour shifts)

      • Holidays

        • Law sets down a minimum length of holiday entitlement for full-time workers

    • Limiting factors

      • Occupational immobility

      • Geographical immobility

      • Occupational choice and opportunity cost

        • Choosing to take up one occupation involves rejecting other occupations
        • Decide what is important(well-paid or job satisfaction)

  • Wage determinant

    • Labour demand

      • The demand for labour refers to the number of workers that firms are willing and able to employ at a given wage rate. Demand for labour is a derived demand(demand for the goods and services it produced, not for itself)

      • Determination factors

        • Price for which that output can be sold

        • Labour productivity

          • The demand for workers increases as their productivity increases, as higher productivity increases the return from hiring workers

        • Demand for the product

          • As the demand for labour is a derived demand. The demand for the goods and services increases, so the demand for labour to produce them will increase

        • Costs of other factors of production

          • An increase in the price of capital may increase the demand for workers as it is possible to substitute labour for capital

    • Labour supply

      • The supply for the labour in an economy consists of people who are of working age and who are both willing and able to work at different wage rates.

      • Determinantion factors

        • Number of labour force

          • A fall in labour force will make an individual business more difficult to recruit workers

        • Qualifications or length of training required to do the job

          • An increase in requirement for qualifications will make the supply of the labour low as the number of people with the willingness and ability to undertake a long period of challenging training is low

        • Non-wage benefits of the job

          • A decrease in non-wage benefits may reduce people’s willingness to do it

        • Wage or non-wage benefits in other jobs

          • A rise in the benefits in other jobs will encourage some workers to switch from one occupation to another

    • Relative bargaining power of employment workers

      • Wages are likely to be higher in occupations where workers have strong bargaining power

      • Trade unions

        • Trade union will use their bargaining strength to negotiate on behalf of their members. A change in trade union’s bargaining power and willingness to take industrial action can affect

      • Level of education

        • A higher level of education will increase the worker’s bargaining power

      • Age and experience

        • An increase in age and experience can increase the worker’s bargaining power and its higher wages.

    • Government policies

      • Clearly influences the wages of those workers whom it employs in the public sector

      • Specific government policies may have an impact on particular occupations

      • Directly affect wages–National Minimum Wage

        • Results

          • If the government introduces an NMW which is above the equilibrium wage, the quantity supplied will extend and the quantity demanded will contract. A surplus of labour appears and results in unemployment

        • Consequences

          • Advantages

            • Workers have a fair or liveable wages and are not exploited by the employers
            • Create incentive for the unemployed to work
            • Low income earners have more money to spend and increase consumption and ease the fears higher wages will cause unemployment

          • Disadvantages

            • Workers who earn more than NMW may ask for a higher wage to maintain the wage differential
            • Unemployment may increase as an increase in costs of labour make firms to purchase more capital goods

    • Public opinion

      • Consider that jobs which involve long periods of study and training should be highly rewarded
      • Influence the wages claims made by the workers
      • Put pressure on a government to revise the wages it pays to the public sector workers
      • Attitudes towards women. If social attitudes are against working women, it is harder for women to find employment and may receive significantly less pay than male counterparts

    • Discrimination

      • It occurs when a group of workers is treated unfavourable in terms of employment, the wage rate, the training received and promotional opportunities

    • Stages of production

      • People work in primary sector may usually less well-paid than those who work in secondary and tertiary sectors.

      • Reasons

        • Workers in primary sector tend to be less skilled and have fewer qualifications
        • With the development of the economy, the demand for primary sector workers usually declines

    • Earnings of individuals over time

      • The longer people work, the more skilled and productive they tend to become. An increase in productivity is caused by gaining experience and undertake training
      • Some older workers may decide to give up working overtime and some may switch to less demanding work, so the wages and bonuses reduces

  • Extent to which earnings change

    • Determinant of elasticity of demand for labour

      • Proportion of labour costs in total costs
      • Ease with which labour can be substituted by capital
      • Elasticity of demand for the product produced
      • Time period

    • Determinant of elasticity of supply of labour

      • Qualifications and skills required
      • Length of training period
      • Level of employment
      • Mobility of labour
      • Degree of vacation
      • Time period

  • Division and specialisation of labour

    • Specialization

      • It occurs when a worker become an experts in a particular profession

    • Division

      • It occurs when a production process or task is split between different workers who become experts in a part of the process

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • Workers become experts in their field, so the productivity and efficiency increases. The average costs of production decreases
        • Quality of the products or services increases
        • Workers become more skilled so their earning potential increases
        • Create higher motivation, productivity, output and competitiveness for the firms

      • Disadvantages

        • Workers may get bored, make more mistakes and decrease productivity
        • Workers may become alienated
        • Become too dependent on an individual workers and be hard to cover for the workers who are off sick or under training
        • Workers become deskilled in other areas and results in a lack of occupational immobility

Market Structure

Competition

  • This create incentive for firms to use their resources efficiently to compete

  • Classification

    • Price competition

      • Competing with rival suppliers on product price. If demand is price inelastic, revenue may fall. If price is lower than the average costs of production, loss may happen.

    • Non-price competition

      • Competing on all other product features other than price

Definition: It refers to the key characteristics of a particular market, including the number and size of firms in the market, the degree and intensity of price and non-price competition and the nature of barriers to entry

Classification

  • Competitive market

    • It is a market structure with the highest level of competition. There is no restriction to entry or exit from the market

    • Characteristic

      • Many suppliers and buyers
      • Low degree of market concentration–Price takers
      • Products must be homogeneous
      • Perfect information
      • No barriers to entry or exit

    • Behaviours

      • Competition

        • Price

          • Price takers and can not make change to the market price

        • Quality

          • Homogeneous products

        • Choice

          • Firms focus on producing differentiated products with different product designs, colours and branding. Large business may use slogans to differentiate their products to improve competitiveness

        • Profit

          • Supernormal profit

            • Attract firms to come into the industry and increase supply which will lower the price and return profit to normal level

          • Loss

            • The firms will reduce supply which increase the price and return profit to normal level

          • Normal profit

            • No change

    • Performance

      • Advantages

        • Promote efficiency
        • Low prices due to competition
        • Produce according to consumers’ wants
        • Wider choices for consumers due to higher number of sellers
        • Good quality goods because of incentive to sell more

      • Disadvantages

        • Price may not be so low as they can not enjoy economies of scale because small scale
        • The choices may be only in sellers instead of a variety of products because of homogeneous products

  • Monopoly

    • It is a sole supplier of a product have 100% share of the market.

    • Characteristic

      • Single supplier and many buyers
      • High degree of market concentration–Price makers
      • Products must be unique
      • Information failure
      • High barriers to entry or exit

    • Behaviours

      • Earn supernormal profits

    • Performance

      • Advantages

        • Enjoy economies of scale. This means they can have low average costs of production and have international competitiveness against foreign competitiors
        • Have financial resources to invest in innovation. Research and development expenditure can help to generate new ideas, products and production processes. Innovation can act as a source of profit and improve productive capacity
        • Eliminate wasteful competition. This is because profit-seeking firms may not have much of a financial incentive to provide services in remote areas of the country and a single provider can gain huge economies of scale.

      • Disadvantages

        • No substitutes. The demand is price inelastic so they can charge higher prices due to price makers to maximise profits
        • High barriers may prevent new firms. This limits the degree of competition and ensure monopolists continue to charge high prices
        • Less incentive to innovate. Because of a lack of competitive pressure, they may become complacent rather than focusing on innovations
        • Market failure. This will result in an inefficient allocation of resources

Producers

Classifications

  • Stages of production

    • Primary sector

      • It contains firms that extract raw materials from the earth

    • Secondary sector

      • It contains firms that manufacture goods changing raw materials into finished goods and construct buildings roads and bridges

    • Tertiary sector

      • It contains firms that provide services to the general public and other firms

  • Ownership

    • Public sector
    • Private sector

  • Size

    • Determinants

      • Number of employees
      • Market share
      • Sales revenue

    • Large firms

    • Medium firms

    • Small firms

      • Advantages

        • Few legal formalities exist

          • Sole traders are quite easy to set up. Start-up costs are also lower than in setting up larger types of business

        • Consumer relationship

          • Know consumers on a more personal level and have better relationship

        • Management

          • Easier to manage and control. Large firms may suffer from diseconomies of scale caused by coordination problems

      • Disadvantages

        • Capital unaffordable

          • Small firms have limited start-up capital, which makes it difficult to raise finance

        • Failure

          • Intense competition causes failure easily

        • Unit cost higher

          • They are unable to exploit the benefits of large-scale production. They may have higher costs of production which will reduce competitiveness and profits

Growth

  • Internal growth

    • Definition: It occurs when firms expand using their own resources

  • External growth

    • Definition: It occurs when expansion involves another organisations

    • Takeover

      • By buying a majority stake in another business. A firm can takeover the target firm and instantly increase its size

    • Merger

      • Definition: It is two firms agree to form one new company

      • Horizontal merger

        • Definition: It occurs between firms engaged in the production of the same type of goods and service at the same stage of production

        • Key motives

          • Take greater advantages of economies of scale
          • Increase the market share
          • Rationalisation: If the two firms had not been fully using the resources, merging may enable them to sell off the redundant resources
          • Save on managerial staff

      • Vertical merger

        • Definition: It occurs when a firm merges with another firm involved with the production of the same product but at a different stage of production

        • Classification

          • Vertical backwards meger

            • Definition: It occurs when a firm from the secondary sector mergers with a firm from the primary sector or a firm from the tertiary industry merges with a firm operating in secondary or primary sector

            • Key motives

              • An adequate supply of good quality raw materials at a reasonable price
              • Restrict the access of the rival firms to the supplies

          • Vertical forwards merger

            • Definition: It occurs when a firm from the primary sector of the industry merges with a firm in secondary or tertiary sector or when a firm from the secondary sector merges with a firm operating in the tertiary sector

            • Key motives

              • Ensure that there are sufficient outlets and the products are stored and displayed well in high quality outlets
              • Help in the development and marketing of new products

      • Conglomerate merger

        • Definition: It occurs when firms from different economic sectors and in unrelated areas of business integrate with one another

        • Key motives

          • Diversification. It spreads a firm’s risks and may enable it to continue its growth

        • Drawbacks

          • Producing a range of products can prove to be very challenging

      • Drawbacks

        • May experience diseconomies of scale
        • Be difficult to control
        • There may be a duplication of resources, so some workers may lose jobs
        • The firms may have been of different sizes and this may require some adjustment or the buying in of some supplies from other firms or the selling of supplies to other firms
        • Management problems. It may not be familiar with running

Results of growth

  • Economies of scale(Advantages)

    • Definition: It is the cost-saving benefits of large-scale of operations which reduce average costs of production

    • Internal economies of scale

      • Average costs fall along the LRAC curve, and reach an optimum point.

      • Types

        • Marketing economies

          • Buying economies

            • Receive a discount when buying raw materials in bulk and placing large orders for capitals, even in terms of better quality and the speed of delivery. Pay less for each item purchased

          • Selling economies

            • Total costs of processing orders and some other processes do not rise in line with the number of orders.
            • Reduce advertising costs. The total costs can be spread over more units and discounts may be secured.

        • Managerial economies

          • Large firms can afford to employ specialist staff as they can spread the pay over a high number of units. This can increase efficiency, reduce costs of production and raise demand and revenue

        • Technical economies

          • Larger the output, more viable to use large technologically advanced machinery to increase efficiency and decrease AVC

        • Financial economies

          • Large firms will find it easier and cheaper to raise finance as banks are more willing to lend to them and charge lower interests

        • Research and development economies

          • Large firms can have a R&D department to reduce costs by developing more efficient production methods and new products

        • Risk bearing economies

          • Large firms produce a range of products to spread risks of trading(shift resources to other products when the profitability of one product falls)

        • Labour economies

          • Large firms can engage in division of labour among their own staff

    • External economies of scale

      • A firm’s average costs will be reduced not by changes in the firm’s output, but by changes in its industry’s output.(A downward shift of a firm’s LRAC curve)

      • Types

        • A skilled labour force

          • A firm can recruit workers who have been trained by other firms in the industry

        • A good reputation

          • An area may gain a reputation for high quality production

        • Specialist suppliers of raw materials and capital goods

          • When an industry becomes large enough, ancillary industry may be set up to provide for the needs of the industry

        • Specialist markets

          • Universities may run courses for workers in large industries. Bank and transport industry may provide services specially designed to meet the particular needs of firms

        • Specialist markets

          • Some large industries have specialist selling places and arrangements

        • Improved infrastructures

          • The growth of an industry may encourage a government and private sector firs to provide better road links and electricity supplies, build new airports and develop dock facilities

  • Diseconomies of scale(Disadvantages)

    • Definition: It occurs when the average costs of production start to increase as the size of a firm increase

    • Internal diseconomies of scale

      • Average costs increase along the LRAC curve starting from the optimum point

      • Types

        • Difficulties controlling the firm

          • Management becomes more complex. Costs of administration will increase and make the firm slower in responding to changes in market condition.

        • Communication problems

          • Hard to ensure everyone has full knowledge about their duties and opportunities
          • May not get opportunity to effectively communicate their views and ideas to management team

        • Poor industrial relation

          • The risk of a lack of motivation of workers and industrial action as workers may have less sense of belonging, longer time to solve problems and more conflict caused by diverse opinions

    • External diseconomies of scale

      • A firm’s average costs will be increased not by changes in the firm’s output, but by changes in its industry’s output. Raise a firm’s LRAC curve at each and every level of output

      • Types

        • Congestion

          • Congestion may happen and cause a decrease in productivity and an increase in costs of production

        • Competition

          • The growth of an industry may increase competition for resources and push up the price of key sites, capital equipment and labour

Production

  • Demand for factors of production

    • Determinant

      • The type of product prodcued
      • Productivity of the factors of production
      • Costs of factors of production

    • Factors influencing demand for capitals

      • Price of capital goods

        • A rise in the price of capitals will cause a contraction in demand for capital

      • Price of other factors of production

        • Substitutes

          • An increase in price of substitutes may increase the demand for capital goods

        • Complements

          • An increase in price of complements may decrease the demand for capital

      • Profit levels

        • If profit levels are high, firms will have incentive and ability to buy capital goods

      • Corporation tax

        • A cut in corporation tax will make firms have more profits available to plough back into business and greater incentive to do the same

      • Income

        • An increase in real income will result in an increase in consumption and encourage firms to invest as they expect to sell a higher output

      • Interest rates

        • A cut in interest rates will reduce the opportunity costs of investing and lower the costs of borrowing
        • A cut in interest rates will encourage consumption and encourage firms to expand their capacity

      • Confidence levels

        • If firms are confident that sales will rise, they will invest now

      • Advances in technology

        • An increase in productivity of capital goods, firms may invest more

    • Factors influencing demand for lands

      • Productivity

        • The most fertile land will be in highest demand and received the highest rent.
        • City centre sites are also very productive as firms have the potential to attract a high number of customers.
        • Natural resource (water) is experiencing an increasing world demand, it has been widely used in domestic agricultural, industrial and energy production purposes.

  • Intensive

    • Classification

      • Capital intensive

        • It occurs when the costs of capital is proportionally higher than the costs of other factors of production

        • This needs a lot of money to fund their activities. This can act as a barrier to entry since it proves expensive for new firms to enter such industries.

        • Consequences

          • Advantages

            • Enable firms to use mass production techniques and increase output
            • Decrease average costs of production
            • Reduce human errors

          • Disadvantages

            • Involve huge set-up costs, running costs and replacement costs
            • Any breakdown may cause major problems because of over-reliance on machinery

      • Labour intensive

        • It occurs when the costs of labour is proportionally higher than the costs of other factors of production

        • Consequences

          • Advantages

            • Be suitable to produce customised products
            • Enables customers to receive a personalised service, so it is appropriate for firms to charge higher prices.
            • Quality of products will be high because of skilled and experienced workers
            • Be more flexible. Labour has flexibly to meet changing levels of demand

          • Disadvantages

            • Price can be high, as high costs of production due to skilled and experienced workers

    • Determinant

      • Costs of labour compared to costs of capital

        • If labour and capital are substitutes, a relative higher labour costs may make firms choose more capital-intensive method of production

      • Size of the market

        • Labour-intensive production is more likely to appear in personalised services
        • Capital-intensive production is more likely to appear in mass-market products

      • Firms’ objectives

        • If the firms in mass market want to maximise the profits, they may choose capital-intensive
        • If the firms want to operate on a smaller scale or to safeguard jobs, they may choose labour-intensive

  • Productivity&Production

    • Production

      • Production is a process of workers combining various inputs in order to make something for consumption. It is the act of creating output, a good or service which has value and contributes to meet people’s needs and wants.

      • Improvement

        • Raising the productivity
        • Using more factors of production

    • Productivity

      • Productivity measures the amount of output that can be produced from a given amount of input.

      • Labour productivity

        • It measures the efficiency of the workforce in terms of output per worker.

        • Improvement

          • Having better-skilled workforce through education and training
          • Allow workers to use better, more efficient technologies

      • Capital productivity

        • It measures the efficiency of the capital in terms of output per capital

        • Improvement

          • Improve technology
          • The use of automation

  • Costs&Revenue

    • Costs

      • Costs of production are the payments made by firms in the production process

      • Total costs

        • Total

          • Definition: Total costs are the sum of all fixed costs and variable costs of production. It is the total costs of producing a given output. Formula: TC=TVC+TFC
          • A line with positive gradient but not straight

        • Average

          • Definition: Average costs are the total costs divided by output
          • A U-shaped curve because of economies and diseconomies of scale

        • Components

          • Fixed costs

            • Total

              • Definition: Fixed costs are payment which do not change with output in the short run
              • A horizontal straight line in the short run
              • Do not exist in the long run

            • Average

              • Definition: Average fixed costs is the total fixed costs divided by output
              • An increase in output causes a decrease in AFC. A straight line with negative gradient

          • Variable costs

            • Total

              • Definition: Variable costs are payment of production that change when the level of output changes
              • As output increases, total variable cost rises. It usually tends to rise slowly at first and then rise more rapidly because of economies of scale and diseconomies of scale
              • A line with positive gradient but not straight

            • Average

              • Definition: Average variable costs are total variable costs divided by output
              • A U-shape curve because of economies and diseconomies of scale

    • Revenue

      • Total

        • Definition: It is the total amount of money received by firms receive through sale of their products and services. Formula: TR=Q*P

      • Average

        • Definition: It is the typical price received from the sale of a good or service. It is same as the price

Objectives

  • Survival

    • At the beginning of a business, their initial objective may be survival
    • During difficult times when demand is falling, large firms may have survival as objectives

  • Growth

    • An increase in size may bring advantages like economies of scale
    • Those who run firms may want the growth as their pay and status may be closely linked to the size of the firm and increase gob security
    • If growth is achieved by merging, competition will be reduced and the company may gain a larger market share

  • Social welfare

    • Public sector companies may aim at improving social welfare through charging relative low prices to ensure they are affordable. Also, they may get to understand the externalities
    • Some private sector firms also show concern about environmental and social effects of their actions.

  • Profit satisficing

    • Make enough dividends to keep shareholders happy while pursuing other objectives

  • Profit maximisation

    • Other objectives may conflict with this, but pursuit of them may actually increase profits in the long run.

    • Formula: profit=revenue-cost; It is maximised when the gap between total revenue and total costs is the highest

    • Effect of changes in profit

      • Provide an incentive with entrepreneurs to undertake production
      • Provide firms with more finance to update their capital equipment and expand their business
      • Make it easier to obtain external finance
      • Easier to recruit top managers and directors, attracted by their success
      • A fall in profit may have little impact on the behaviour of firms in the short run. But in the long run, firms may cut back on production and cease production

    • Ways of increasing profit

      • Reduce costs of production

        • Reduce any wastages and inefficiency
        • Increase the productivity of factors of production
        • Increase the size of the firm to enjoy economies of scale or stronger market power to make demand be inelastic

      • Raise revenue

        • Improve the quality of their products, diversify and be more responsive to changes in consumer demand
        • Increase output
        • Advertising

Trade unions

Definition: Trade unions are organisations that promote and protect the interests of their members(employees) to improve their wages and working conditions

Classification

  • Craft unions

    • These represents workers with particular skills. These workers may be employed in a number of industries

  • General unions

    • These unions include workers with a range of skills and from a range of industries.(usually have a large membership of unskilled workers)

  • Industrial unions

    • These seeks to represent all the workers in a particular industry

  • White-collar unions

    • These unions represent particular professions

Functions

  • Bargaining with employers for pay rises

    • Basis of wage claims

      • Work harder and increase productivity
      • An industry with higher profits can afford to pay higher wages.(Workers are likely to have contributed to the higher profits)
      • Comparability argument. Workers in comparable occupations who have received a wage increase
      • A rise in the cost of living due to inflation which reduces the real wages. A wage rise is needed to meet the increased of cost of living

  • Negotiate on behalf of their members on job security, working hours and working conditions.

  • Protect or improve workers’ rights

  • Provide information on a range of issues for their members

  • Help with education and training schemes

  • Participate in measures designed to increase demand for the product produced

  • Ensure members are given legal advice when necessary

  • Give support to members when they are made redundant

  • Provide financial and legal support to workers who may have been unfairly dismissed or disciplined

  • Pressuring governments to adopt legislation in favour of workers

Factors affecting the strength of a trade union

  • A high number of members

    • The more the members a union has, the more funds it has to finance its activities.
    • It is difficult to replace union labour by non-union labour.

  • A high level of skills

    • Unions with skilled workers are in a relative strong position as it is difficult to replace skilled workers with other skilled workers and expensive to train unskilled workers

  • A consistent demand for product produced by the workers

    • Unions that represent workers making essential goods and services are in strong position to bargain

  • Favourable government legislation

    • If the governments allow industrial action, the trade union will be in a stronger position

  • A high level of economic activity

    • If output and income in a country increase, more industries may perform well, so wages and non-wage factors may improve. Also, when output reaches high levels and most people are employed, firms may compete for workers. So bargaining power increases

Ways

  • Collective bargaining

    • Definition: The trade union acts as a means of communication and negotiation between employers and employees through a process called collective bargaining

  • Industrial actions

    • Overtime ban

      • Workers refuse to work more than their normal hours

    • Work to rule

      • Workers deliberately slow down production by complying rigidly with every rule and regulation

    • Go-slow

      • Workers carry out tasks deliberately slowly to reduce production

    • Strike

      • Workers refuse to work and may also protest or picket outside their workplace to stop deliveries and prevent non-unionised workers from entering

Consequences

  • Advantages

    • Provide a channel of communication between employers and employees. This makes firms less time consuming, less stressful and cheaper to negotiate with workers as a group
    • They encourage workers to engage in education and training to raise productivity
    • Provide workers with an outlet to vent discontent and channel their grievances to the employers to reduce conflict
    • Benefit non-unionised workers with higher wages and better working conditions

  • Disadvantages

    • Taking industrial action may result in lost productivity
    • Increase the costs of production and reduce profits. This will cause the government revenue decreases as well

entry.content:
Government

Roles

  • The general role of the government is to improve the general welfare of its people.

  • Local

    • Provide a range of goods and services
    • Raise some taxes

  • National

    • Central government makes decisions about how to achieve macroeconomic aims. It does this with appropriate macroeconomic policies

    • As a producer

      • Ensure their key industries, including strategic industries or national champions, survive and do well by running state-owned enterprises
      • Run a natural monopoly and produce essential products
      • Produce or finance the output of public goods and may produce merit goods

    • As a partner of private sectors

      • Private sector initially provides the finance for a state project. Private sector firm builds it and maintain it for a number of years. Government rents it and operates it, buying it back over time
      • The public and private sectors provide part of a service. eg. private sector firms run train operating companies whilst the government builds and maintains the infrastructure

    • As an employer

      • Employ workers and managers to operate state-owned enterprises to reduce unemployment, control rises in prices and set an example in terms of employment practice

  • International

    • Promote free international trade or impose restrictions on international trade
    • Vary in policies towards foreign multinational companies
    • May be member of trade blocs which promote trade between the member countries and may restrict trade with non-members, or be member of international organisations which deal with global rules of trade between members to promote free international trade

Economic Growth

Measurement

  • Gross Domestic Production(GDP)

    • Definition: GDP is the total market value of all final goods and services produced in a country in a give year

    • Components

      • Consumption

        • This refers to the total spending on goods and services by individuals and households in an economy

      • Government spending

        • This is the total consumption and investment expenditure of the government(ignoring payments made without any corresponding output, eg. unemployment benefit)

      • Investment

        • This refers to the capital spending of firms used to increase production and to expand the economy’s productive capacity

      • Net export

        • Net export=export earnings-import revenue
        • Export earnings measures the monetary value of all exports sold to foreign buyers
        • Import revenue measure the monetary value of all imports

    • Classification

      • Nominal GDP

        • It is GDP valued in terms of the prices operative at that time

      • Real GDP

        • It is GDP at constant prices and so adjusted for inflation
        • Economists calculate it by multiplying nominal GDP with the price index in the base year, divided by the price index in the current year

      • GDP per head

        • GDP per head=real GDP/population

    • Calculating

      • Ways of calculating

        • Output

          • Adding up the output produced by all the industries in the country. Economists include the ‘value added’ by each firm at each stage of production

        • Income

          • Include all the incomes which have been earned in producing the country’s output

        • Expenditure

          • Adding up all the expenditure on the country’s finished output. It is necessary to add exports and deduct imports

      • Difficulties to calculate real GDP

        • GPD tends to understate the true level of output due to existence of informal economy, including undeclared and non-market economies.
        • Factors that influence the size of the informal economy includes：
          number of activities that are declared illegal; tax rates; penalties for tax evasion; number of tasks people perform for themselves; the size of subsistence agriculture

Results of change in GDP

  • Economic Growth–Real GDP increases

    • Definition: It is an increase in its output in the short run and an increase in the economy’s productive potential in the long run

    • Classification

      • Actual economic growth

        • Movement of a point closer with PPC–More capital and consumer goods are made

      • Potential economic growth

        • PPC shifts outwards–The economy is capable of producing more

    • Causes

      • Actual

        • An increase in any components of AD may stimulate a rise in output if the economy has unused resources.

      • Potential

        • An increase in the quantity or quality of resources

          • Discovery of new resources
          • Investment in capitals and infrastructure
          • Technical progress
          • More and better healthcare, education and training
          • A more efficient resource allocation

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • Improve living standards. Higher income levels increase people’s access to more goods and services.
        • Increase government tax revenue. The tax revenue can be used to reduce poverty and sustain the growth of the economy
        • Employment. An increase of output to achieve higher demand will make the employment rise
        • Stable price. Output increases to match higher demand, upward pressure on the price level can be avoided
        • Higher trade position. Some of the extra output may be exported.

      • Disadvantages

        • Short-run opportunity costs. Resources shift from making consumer goods to capital goods and results in a decrease in living standards
        • Increase pollution and destroy wildlife habitats
        • Depletion of non-renewable resources and damage the natural environment
        • Greater stree on workers
        • Inflation. An increase in AD may results in demand-pull inflation.

  • Recession–Real GDP decreases

    • Definition: Recession occurs when real GDP declines over a period of six months or more.

    • Causes

      • A decrease in aggregate demand

        • Higher interest rate which discourages consumption
        • A decrease in consumer confidence
        • Lower rates of disposable income results in a fall in consumption
        • A decrease in government spending
        • A decline in the demand for exports

      • A decrease in aggregate supply

        • A higher level of unemployment
        • Higher interest rate which discourage investment due to an increase in costs of borrowing
        • A decrease in government spending in investment and infrastructure
        • Low business confidence

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • If recession is caused by a decrease in AD, the price level will fall

      • Disadvantages

        • If recession is caused by a decrease in AS, the price level will increase and results in inflation
        • Unemployment may rise because of a decrease in output. This will cause a decrease in living standards due to the reduction in output and incomes
        • Investment is discouraged which will endanger future economic growth
        • Tax revenue will decline so government spending may fall and increase budget deficit

  • Trade cycle

    • It describes the fluctuations in the economic activity of a country over time, creating a long-term trend of economic growth in the economy.

Policies to promote economic growth

  • With spare capacity

    • Expansionary fiscal policy–A reduction in income tax rates
    • Monetary policy–A cut in interest rate

  • Without spare capacity

    • Supply-side policy

Low unemployment

Criteria

  • Impossible to achieve 0% unemployment due to changing jobs and being unemployed for short periods
  • Aim for low unemployment below 3%(vary between countries and over time)

Measurements

  • Unemployment rate

    • Components

      • Definition: Employment refers to the economic use of labour as a factor of production.(including those who are self-employed)
      • Definition: Unemployment occurs when people of working age are both willing and able to work but cannot find employment
      • Definition: Labour force refers to people who are both willing and able to work
      • Formula: Unemployment rate=employment/labour force*100

    • Ways of calculating

      • Claimant count(count those in receipt of unemployment-related benefits)

        • Consequences

          • Advantages

            • Relative cheap and quick

          • Disadvantages

            • Understate unemployment

      • Carry out labour force surveys(LFS)

        • It uses a standardised household-based survey to collect work-related statistics

Changes

  • Pattern of employment

    • Industrial structure

      • Performance

        • As economies develop employment moves from the primary to the secondary and then to the tertiary sector
        • Some industry will be expanding and some will contracting.

      • This requires workers to be occupationally and geographically mobile

    • Proportion of women in employment

      • Because of better social attitudes, gender discrimination is declining. Higher number and proportion of women in employment increase

    • Proportion of workers in the public and private sectors

      • As more countries are moving closer to market economy, the number and proportion of workers in public sector is declining

    • Full-time and part-time work

      • Most workers work full-time.

    • Employed and self-employed

      • The rate of self employment varies amongst countries.

    • Informal and formal economies

      • Lack of benefits. Workers in informal economies may not have the same access to the social security benefits, employment protection and rights.
      • With the development of economy, number and proportion of workers in formal economy increases.
      • A growth in formal economy will raise the quality of employment and labour productivity

    • High and low quality employment

      • High quality

        • It is skilled work which is interesting and which provides workers with the opportunity to have better non-wage factors of jobs

      • Low quality

        • It is unskilled work which often does not require or provide training and does not provide good working conditions

      • As an economy develops the proportion of high quality jobs tends to increase.

    • Flexible employment

      • Global competition is putting pressure on firms to ensure that their labour force is flexible. A flexible labour force is one which adjust quickly and smoothly to changes in market conditions

      • Classification

        • Numerical flexibility

          • The easier it is to hire and fire workers, the more able firms are in adjusting their output in line with consumer demand
          • Increase workers’ sense of job security and employment

        • Temporal flexibilty

          • Ability to change the number of hours people work

        • Locational flexibility

          • Ability to change the location where workers work

        • Functional flexibility

          • Ability to change the tasks workers perform

        • Wage flexibility

          • Ability to raise or lower wages

  • Levels of employment

    • A rise in employment may reduce unemployment if it is the unemployed who fill at least some of these jobs.

    • If the labour force grows faster than increase in employment, both employment and unemployment increase

    • If the employed reach retirement age, have full time education, emigrate and stop searching work, unemployment falls without an increase in employment

    • Measurement

      • Labour force participation rate

        • It is the proportion of the working-age population who are in the labour force

        • Formula: participation rate=labour force/working age

        • Factors influencing

          • Wages on offer
          • Social attitudes to working women
          • Provision for care of children and the elderly
          • Social attitudes and provision for the disabled to work
          • Proportion of school leavers who go into higher education
          • Age of retirement

Unemployment

  • Causes

    • Frictional unemployment

      • Definition: It is the transitional unemployment which occurs when people change jobs due to the time delay between leaving a job and finding or starting a new one

      • Classification

        • Search unemployment

          • It occurs when workers do not accept the first job offered but spend time looking around for what they regard as an ‘acceptable job’

        • Seasonal unemployment

          • It is temporary unemployment because some production and consumer demand is seasonal, whose labour is not in demand at certain periods of the year

        • Casual unemployment

          • It occurs when people are out of work between periods of employment

    • Structural unemployment

      • Definition: It is the unemployment resulting from changes in the pattern of demand and supply in economy

      • Causes

        • Another countries becoming better at producing the product
        • A substitute being found for the product
        • Capital being substituted for labour

      • Classification

        • Regional unemployment

          • It is caused by a decline in job opportunities in a particular area of the country

        • Technological unemployment

          • It occurs when workers are made redundant as a result of advances in ICT

      • Structural employment is more serious than frictional unemployment as it persists for longer periods and usually affects more workers

    • Cyclical unemployment

      • Definition: It is prolonged and widespread unemployment during an economic recession due to falling and depressed aggregate demand
      • It is more serious than structural unemployment as potentially it can affect more workers and it is spread throughout the country

    • The extent and seriousness of these costs are influenced by the numbers unemployed and length of time for which they are unemployed

  • Consequences

    • Advantages

      • Make it easier for firms, wishing to expand to recruit new workers
      • Keep down inflationary pressure by lowering wage rises

    • Disadvantages

      • The unemployed

        • A fall in income
        • A loss of self-worth
        • A decline in mental and physical health
        • Marriage break-ups in some cases
        • An adverse effect on the education of the children of the unemployed and their enployment chances
        • Reduce chances of gaining another job
        • Lose out on training in new method and technology
        • Lose the work habit and confidence may dip

      • Firms

        • High unemployment may mean a low demand for products so firms may reducing production instead of expanding

      • Economy

        • Unemployment is a waste of resources(use PPC to show)
        • Tax revenue will be low due to a decrease in corporation tax, income tax and indirect tax
        • Put pressure on government expenditure as expenditure on unemployment benefits and healthcare will increase
        • Crime may increase crime which aims to gain higher income. Government may spend more to tackle problems and ensure the security

Policies to achieve full employment

  • Frictional unemployment

    • Supply-side policy to improve the working of the labour market. eg. increase the gap between pay and unemployment benefits
    • Increase information on job vacancies

  • Structural unemployment

    • Supply-side policy

      • Education and training
      • Subsidies to new industries in areas of high unemployment

  • Cyclical unemployment

    • Expansionary fiscal policy

      • An increase in government expenditure
      • A reduction in tax rates

    • Expansionary monetary policy

      • A cut in interest rate

  • How effective

    • Whether the government has identified the cause of unemployment correctly

Price stability

Criteria that governments set for inflation

  • Set a target inflation rate of 2% or a rather higher rate

  • Reasons

    • Measure of inflation tend to overstate rises in prices. eg. an increase in price is caused by an improvement in products due to improvement in details or technology
    • A slight rise in prices can provide some benefits. eg. encourage producers to increase output

Measurement

  • CPI(Consumer price index)

    • It is a measure of the weighted average of the prices of a representative basket goods and services

    • Steps taken to calculate

      • Selecting a base year

        • Select a relatively standard year in which there were no dramatic changes as a base year and give it a CPI or 100 and the price levels in other countries are compared to this figure

      • Finding out how households spend their money

        • It is important to know how people spend their money and determine the weight
        • The weights of these items in price index will be altered to reflect the proportional changes

      • Finding out price changes

        • Every month government officials find out information about prices. The government estimates the changes in prices

      • Constructing a weighted price index

        • Multiple the weighs by the new price index for each category of products and to calculate the change in general price leve;

Results of change in CPI

  • Inflation

    • Definition: It is the sustained rise in the general price level in an economy over time

    • Causes

      • Cost-push inflation

        • It occurs when the price level is pushed up by increases in the costs of production. As costs are higher, producers will raise their prices to maintain their profit margins

        • Reasons

          • Wages increase more than labour productivity
          • Increase in the cost of raw materials
          • Increase in indirect taxes
          • Higher cost of capital goods
          • Increase in profit margins by firms

      • Demand-pull inflation

        • It occurs when the price level is pulled up by an excess demand

        • Reasons

          • Higher consumption, higher investment, higher government expenditure, higher net export
          • A shortage of some resources so it is not possible to produce any more output

    • Consequences

      • Determinants

        • Inflation rate
        • Stability of this rate
        • Rate relative to the inflation rates in other countries
        • Reaction of the government

      • Advantages

        • Encourage firms to expand
        • Reduce the real burden of any debt
        • Prevent some workers being made redundant in a declining industry or region as they may accept their wages rising by less than inflation

      • Disadvantages

        • Producer

          • Menu costs are costs involved in changing prices in catalogues, price lists and slot machines
          • Shoe leather costs arise because money paid to firms will be losing its value as son as it is received. Seeking out good financial returns will involve the time and effort of firms

        • A fall in the value of money. There will be a fall in the real income and purchasing power.

        • Redistribute income in an unplanned way

          • Savers will lose out from inflation because the money they saved is worth less than before. Also, this discourages saving and reduce bond which results in lower investment
          • Borrowers gain from inflation as the money they need to repay is worth less than when they initially borrowed it
          • Lenders will lose out from inflation because the money they lent out to borrowers becomes worth less than before
          • Fixed income earners and pensioners will have a fall in their real income

        • Uncertainty. It makes it harder to judge right prices and plan ahead. Firms may be discouraged from investment

        • Harm balance of payment. If the country’s inflation rate is above that of its rivals, its products will become less price competitive so export will fall and import will increase. Unemployment may appear meanwhile

        • Fiscal drag. When government don’t adjust tax brackets in line with inflation, so people’s incomes are dragged into higher tax brackets and they are left with lower real disposable income

    • Policies to control

      • Demand-pull inflation

        • Contractionary fiscal policy

          • Increase tax or reduce government spending, but this may not work if consumers are very confident about the future

        • Contractionary monetary policy

          • Changing interest rates to control the level of economic activities.

      • Cost-push inflation

        • Supply-side policies

  • Deflation

    • Definition: It is the sustained fall in the general price level in an economy over time

    • Causes

      • Beneficial

        • Advances in technology and increase in labour productivity may reduce price level. Consumers can enjoy more products and country be more internationally competitive

      • Harmful

        • A decline in AD. Consumers may expect prices to be lower so they may decrease purchase and output will decrease. Unemployment may increase.

    • Consequences

      • Beneficial deflation

        • Reduce a current account deficit or increase a current account surplus if demand is elastic and exchange rate remains unchanged
        • Increase output and employment

      • Harmful deflation

        • A fall in demand may cause a fall in the demand for labour and increase unemployment
        • Consumers spend less so firms may have lower revenue to repay costs and liabilities. Bankruptcies may appear
        • Decrease consumer confidence so they will spend less and results in a downwards deflationary spiral
        • Real costs of debts increase. This will make consumers and firms decrease confidence
        • Government debts. Government may need to pay more unemployment benefits and have less revenue, so budget deficit may appear

    • Policies to control

      • Expansionary fiscal policy

        • A cut in direct ta may increase real income and aggregate demand, higher levels of economic activities may appear. Unemployment may decrease and economic growth may appear

      • Expansionary monetary policy

        • Lower interest rate may reduce exchange rate so price of imports increase and demand for exports will increase

Policies

Demand-side policies

  • Fiscal policy

    • Definition: It is decision on changing government spend and taxation to achieve the macroeconomy aims of the government

    • Budget

      • Components

        • Government expenditure

          • Components

            • Debt interest, defence, education, environment, healthcare, housing, law and order, postal services, roads, sewage systems, transport and welfare benefits

          • Reasons

            • To influence economic activity. Increase its spending to increase AD to stimulate more output and results in economic growth
            • To reduce market failure. Spend on public goods and merits goods. Still, they spend money regulating markets
            • To promote equity. Provide benefits to vulnerable groups and the unemployed.

        • Government revenue

          • Components

            • Tax revenues including direct and indirect tax
            • Non-tax revenues including fines, tolls, fees and penalties, foreign aids, loans, revenue from state-owned enterprise and donations

          • Taxation

            • Reasons

              • To redistribute income from the rich to the poor
              • To discourage the consumption of demerit goods
              • To reduce negative externalities by raising the costs of firms
              • To discourage the consumption of imports and protect domestic industries with tariffs
              • To influence economic activity

            • Classification

              • Percentage

                • Progressive tax

                • Proportional tax

                • Regressive tax

                  • Definition: It is tax which takes a larger percentage of the income or wealth of the poor

                    • Inheritance tax

                • Indirect tax

                  • Definition: It is the expenditure tax imposed on spending on goods and services

              • Equity

              • Certainty

              • Convenience

                • A tax should be easy to pay

              • Economy

                • The costs of collecting should be less than tax revenue

              • Flexibility

                • It should be easy to change the tax if economic activity changes and government aims change

              • Efficiency

                • It should improve the performance of markets or at least not reduce the efficiency

            • Impact

              • Tax base and tax burden

                • Tax burden

              • Taxation

                • Elasticity

                    • If the supply is more price inelastic, the more tax will be borne by the suppliers

                • Economic growth

                  • Tax may discourage workers to work.

                  • Tax revenue helps government spending and makes contribution to economic growth

                • Business location

                  • The tax rate of direct tax will affect MNCs locations

                • Social behavior

                  • Taxation can be used to alter social behaviour by reducing the consumption of demerit goods.

                • Distribution of income

                  • Taxes can be used to help redistribute income and wealth from the relatively rich to the poorer members of society.

      • Results

          • It occurs when government spends the same as it collects from its revenue

        • Budget deficit

          • Definition: It occurs when government spends more than it collects from its revenue

Stages

Indicators of economic development

  • HDI

Causes of differences in economic development between countries

  • Income

    • The higher the real GDP per head, the greater economic development tends to be.

    • Problems

      • Inequalities in distribution of income
      • Composition of GDP should be considered
      • Economic growth can bring about problems, so other factors should also be considered

  • Productivity

    • Higher productivity will make it easier to develop
    • Foreign direct investment will increase productivity in quantity and quality of FOPs so increase the productive capacity and competitiveness, create jobs

  • Population growth

    • countries with high population growth may have a high dependency ratio so government will spend more in education
    • Rapid population growth can limit any increase in real GDP as it reduces the GDP per capita.

  • Size of primary, secondary and tertiary sectors

    • As an economy develops, there tends to be a shift away from reliance on primary and secondary sector production towards tertiary.

  • Saving

    • Due to different income, poor people can’t afford to save so the country with low average income may have low savings ratio. This will be a lack of finance for investment

  • Investment

    • Countries with low value of capital goods per worker may have low income per head
    • Countries with low savings may be hard for firms to borrow, so investment may be low and can’t contribute directly to economic development

  • Education and healthcare

    • A lack of access to or poor quality of education and healthcare will reduce living standards and low productivity

  • Concentration on a narrow range of exports

Why aim for economic development

  • Higher real GDP, higher living standards and expansion of the range of economic and social choices
  • Have potential to raise material living standards
  • Enjoy more goods and services
  • Life expectancy may be increased and infant mortality rate may be reduced
  • Higher living standards
  • Distribution of income does not become too uneven and poverty is reduced
  • Expanding the range of economic and social choices, increasing freedom and self-esteem includes increasing access to education, healthcare and participation in the political process. This will improve the quality of lives and enhance future economic performance
  • Increase international competitiveness

Problems facing economies with relatively low economic development

  • High growth of population

    • A high birth rate can result in resources being used
    • In the low run, higher birth rate increases the country’s productive potential and living standards

  • High levels of international debt

    • Opportunity cost of repaying debt may be economic development. As poor countries may borrow heavily, a large percentage of country’s income is taken up in repaying loans

  • Reliance on the export of primary products

    • The price of primary products tends to fall so they receive less for exports and pay more for imports.
    • Consuming and rich countries use their buying power to keep down the prices

  • Lack of investment in capitals and humans

    • This may hold back the increases in productivity, introduction of new technology and international competitiveness

  • Emigration of key workers

    • Key workers may seek better-paid employment abroad

  • Trade restrictions on their products

    • Tariffs make it difficult for developing countries to sell their products at home and abroad.
    • Tariffs also build up as the goods are processed into higher-value-added goods, so that economies are discouraged from building up their industries

  • Unbalanced economies

    • Certain markets may be under-developed such as the financial sector. A lack of developed financial sector is likely to discourage saving and investment

  • Classification of specialisation

      • Better quality of the product as an improvement in skills and techniques

      • May not follow the same health and safety standards as the home country
